Mr Bainimarama said the government had widened its testing to all close contacts of every confirmed case regardless of whether they were displaying symptoms.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200501033925/https://www.rnz.co.nz/international/pacific-news/414433/fiji-declares-second-state-of-natural-disaster-as-covid-19-cases-increase

Localised lockdowns have been lifted, but some business sectors must remain closed across Fiji: Nightclubs, gyms, cinemas, swimming pools, and houses of worship to remain closed.     http://archive.vn/P3Jz2
Last lockdown eases:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200609105822/https://www.fbcnews.com.fj/news/covid-19/vunicagi-settlement-restriction-lifted/

'We’ll be permitting live sporting events to resume, but with restrictions. Our formal indoor and outdoors sporting venues can host sporting events with spectators at 50 per cent capacity, so long as physical distancing is maintained within the venue. For informal sports events at the community level, the 100-person limit applies. '  http://archive.fo/T7zX8

The MINISTRY OF COMMERCE, TRADE, TOURISM & TRANSPORT website notes that since June 21st Fiji is implementing Phase 2 of its "COVID Safe Economic Recovery (Framework)" (see link below). There is a link to the Framework on this page which opens a PDF covering the policies in each phase of the plan.   For face coverings, Phase 2 details some recommended and some mandatory situations for the wearing of masks. For gatherings such as weddings, the policy is "Strongly encourage the use of PPE, such as face covering".  For domestic travel mask wearing is "strongly encouraged". For hair dressers, beauty services and spas, "employees must wear face coverings when serving clients" and it is mandatory where physical distancing of greater than 1.5m is not possible.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201014124120/https://www.mcttt.gov.fj/doc_uploads/Tourism%20Guidelines.pdf     http://archive.today/2020.10.12-112252/https://www.mcttt.gov.fj/guidelines/covid-19-guidelines/covid-19-important-guidelines/

'From Monday, the 22nd of June, we’ll be relaxing this restriction, allowing for gatherings up to 100 individuals. For the time being, this 100-person limit will apply to weddings, funerals, cafes, restaurants, conferences and other community gatherings.'  http://archive.fo/T7zX8

According to UK FCO, domestic travel is 'returning to normal' however as of June 22, "If you’re looking to leave Fiji and are visiting the outer islands, you’re advised to return to the main island of Viti Levu immediately. Further cases of Covid-19 in Fiji could see the reintroduction of restrictions on internal travel and/or a lockdown of affected areas. If you remain in the outer islands there is no guarantee you will be able to leave for some time." http://archive.fo/un42A

30 June  Students return to school. Fijian Government Facebook ‘Minister Welcomes First Batch of Children Back to School. The Hon. Minister for Education, Heritage and Arts, Rosy Akbar welcomes Years 12 and 13 students back to school after three months of school closure. The Ministry of Education was encouraged to see a high number of students turn up for school today, over 100 days after schools were closed due to the global COVID-19 pandemic. The Ministry recorded a turnout of over 70%.  "We would like to thank all our lovely children and encourage you all to continue going to school and make the best of the free education provided by the Fijian Government," said Minister for Education, Hon. Rosy Akbar”      Government Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200728150237/https://www.facebook.com/MOEFIJI/posts/2062900917178289?__tn__=-R  Media Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200720025614/https://www.fbcnews.com.fj/news/covid-19/decision-to-reopen-schools-not-rushed/

The schools were open and the minister welcomed both students and teachers. Social distancing and hygiene measures are in place. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20201129225339/https://www.fiji.gov.fj/Media-Centre/News/MINISTER-WELCOMES-TEACHERS-BACK-TO-SCHOOL
"Domestic travel is returning to normal". https://web.archive.org/web/20200727224748/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/fiji/coronavirus
"Gatherings of up to 100 individuals are now allowed. This applies to weddings, funerals, conferences, community gatherings, cafes and restaurants."

As of 25th August 2020, gatherings (which were limited to 100 people) will now be increased to 250 people.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200831153129/http://www.health.gov.fj/statement-by-ps-health-on-border-case-and-covid-safe-amendments/

The change of code to a 3 reflects the immigration rule concerning yachts in the "Blue Lanes" scheme.  As yachts are allowed entry if they satisfy various requirements of the Fiji authorities, the conclusion is that - although limited in scale - the borders are open to some who are not citizens of Fiji.  As such, a code of "4" referring to banning arrival from all regions or total border closure would not reflect the situation.  "Fiji has established a safe “blue lanes”, open to those yachts and pleasure craft sailing to Fiji. Any boat coming to Fiji will be carefully considered on a case-by-case basis. The only port of entry will be Port Denarau Marina. If this pilot project and if successful, extending blue lanes to other ports and marinas will be considered."  Link: http://archive.today/2020.10.12-080639/http://www.immigration.gov.fj/

Government document suggesting screening of people suspected of having COVID.  “Translated: Screen - Suspected patient = Clinical picture (<14 days after exposure) AND Compatible exposure  Original: Dépister - Patient suspect = Tableau clinique (<14 jours après exposition) ET Exposition compatible””  https://web.archive.org/web/20200519161609/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/2019-ncov-fichesoignants22janv-vf.pdf    31/01  About 200 French people, who live in Wuhan, were repatriated and placed in isolation in a holiday centre near Marseille.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201109001830/https://www.lefigaro.fr/sciences/2020/01/31/01008-20200131LIVWWW00001-en-direct-coronavirus-les-rapatries-francais-attendus-pres-de-marseille.php

Face mask wearing strongly recommended in a medical situation if patient is suspected of having COVID. Also for caregivers and for contact tracers in these situations where COVID is potentially present.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200519161609/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/IMG/pdf/2019-ncov-fichesoignants22janv-vf.pdf    "? Patient: hydro-alcoholic solutions (AHS) then wearing a surgical mask, isolation in a pre-identified single room.  ? Caregiver: reinforced standard precautions REB "air" and "contact" => SHA, FFP2 type mask, gown for use  single use, non-sterile disposable gloves, protective goggles (in case of treatment liable to generate aerosols).  ? Pre-identification of contact persons: by EOH for HE professionals and patients, to be continued by ARS."

FAQ of government: Distribution of flyers in English, Mandarin, and French at airports beginning on January 24 (déploiement de flyers et d’affiches d’information en français, anglais et mandarin dans les aéroports); https://web.archive.org/web/20200402111143/http://www.essonne.gouv.fr/content/download/30487/234871/file/FAQ%2520-%2520COVID-19%2520-%2520260220.pdf

Testing and subsequent contact tracing starts  "25 janvier : mise en place d’une procédure d’identification et de suivi des cas contacts personnalisée et quotidienne a été mise en place via les ARS."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200228164045/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

"25 janvier : mise en place d’une procédure d’identification et de suivi des cas contacts personnalisée et quotidienne a été mise en place via les ARS."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200228164045/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus

FAQ of government: Information posters rolled out nationwide at train stations; https://web.archive.org/web/20200402111143/http://www.essonne.gouv.fr/content/download/30487/234871/file/FAQ%2520-%2520COVID-19%2520-%2520260220.pdf

France bans large indoor gatherings with more than 5000 attendees. Measures announced after an emergency cabinet meeting also include the cancellation of the Paris half-marathon which was to be held on Sunday. Among the events affected by the prohibition of large indoor gatherings is Paris's annual agricultural fair. Its final day, which was scheduled for Sunday, has been cancelled.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200625172238/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-51690657    The government has also banned all public gatherings in the Oise district north of Paris and in La Balme-de-Sillingy, a town in the French Alps where cases have been reported. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health-france/france-bans-gatherings-of-more-than-5000-due-to-coronavirus-idUSKBN20N0MD

Generally, indoor gatherings of over 5000 people are banned in France.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200813095342/https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-51690657  In the worst hit area of north Paris, all pubic gatherings are banned, hence the 4T coding instead of 1G. "The government has also banned all public gatherings in the Oise district north of Paris and in La Balme-de-Sillingy, a town in the French Alps where cases have been reported." https://web.archive.org/web/20200813095405/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-china-health-france/france-bans-gatherings-of-more-than-5000-due-to-coronavirus-idUSKBN20N0MD  "In the department of Oise, the main epidemic center, and in the town of La Balme-de-Sillingy, in Haute-Savoie, all public gatherings - including masses - are prohibited "until further notice"." https://web.archive.org/web/20200813095458/https://www.lemonde.fr/politique/article/2020/02/29/coronavirus-le-gouvernement-decide-l-interdiction-des-rassemblements-de-plus-de-5-000-personnes-en-milieu-confine-et-de-certains-autres-en-milieu-ouvert-dont-le-semi-marathon-de-paris_6031356_823448.html An excellent summary can be found at: http://web.archive.org/web/20201208203331/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/les-actions-du-gouvernement

Le Figaro is among the established media outlets reporting that all schools in 12 municipalities of Oise and Morbihan (in Northern France and Brittany) are closed from Monday, 2 March 2020 until at least 14 March, 2020. Archived report (in French): https://web.archive.org/web/20200514222523/https://etudiant.lefigaro.fr/article/coronavirus-les-ecoles-de-neuf-communes-de-l-oise-sont-fermees-pour-14-jours_28d727a8-5c60-11ea-8a33-ca35e4bd44df/

Prime Minister Édouard Philippe has asked citizens to work from home and to only go outside to buy essential supplies, take light exercise, and vote in this weekend’s local elections. All non-essential businesses will be closed and although public transport will remain open, Mr Philippe encouraged residents to limit their use, telling them not to travel between towns unless essential. Archived report: http://web.archive.org/web/20200408102620/https://metro.co.uk/2020/03/14/france-becomes-latest-country-go-lockdown-battle-coronavirus-12398948/?ito=cbshare

National education minister Jean-Michel Blanquer announces school closures. "From Monday March 16, the order will affect all educational establishments and those that look after children during the day, from all crèches to some universities. This includes primary schools, collèges and lycées."  https://twitter.com/franceinter/status/1238361185549987840?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1238361185549987840&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.connexionfrance.com%2FFrench-news%2FCovid-19-coronavirus-in-France-All-the-questions-answered-so-far-as-Macron-and-minister-announce-school-closures-to-halt-virus  https://web.archive.org/web/20200417222135/https://www.cnbc.com/2020/03/13/coronavirus-france-shuts-schools-to-avoid-being-the-next-italy.html

"Public transport in built-up areas will be maintained to allow the French to carry out the strictly necessary trips," explained Elisabeth Borne. Longer distance transport between urban areas - by train, coach and plane - will be progressively reduced in order to limit the spread of the virus on national territory. But everyone can return to their home, there will be no sudden stop and no full stop.    la ministre de la transition écologique et solidaire, Elisabeth Borne, et le secrétaire d’Etat aux transports, Jean-Baptiste Djebbari, ont détaillé, dimanche matin, plusieurs mesures d’adaptation à cette nouvelle donne. « Les transports en commun en agglomération seront maintenus pour permettre aux Français d’accomplir les déplacements strictement nécessaires, a expliqué Elisabeth Borne. Les transports de plus longue distance entre les agglomérations – par train, car et avion – seront progressivement réduits afin de limiter la propagation du virus sur le territoire national. Mais tout le monde pourra retourner vers son domicile, il n’y aura pas d’arrêt brutal et pas d’arrêt complet. » https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.lemonde.fr/economie/article/2020/03/16/a-travers-l-hexagone-les-transports-en-mode-virus_6033189_3234.html    “We must absolutely limit movement, meetings and contacts,” French prime minister Edouard Philippe said on Saturday evening. Food shops, tobacconists, banks and public transport will remain open, he said.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200425101434/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/14/france-closes-non-essential-public-spaces-due-to-coronavirus      Long-distance transport (trains, buses, planes) will be "gradually reduced". There will be around 80% of traffic on the metro. http://web.archive.org/web/20200425102359/https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/Covid-19-in-France-Transport-trains-buses-planes-SNCF-gradually-reduced-says-transport-minister

L’État a mis en place, avec les Régions, un fonds de solidarité doté d’1,7 milliard d’euros pour le mois de mars qui permettra le versement d’une aide défiscalisée allant jusqu’à 1500 euros aux plus petites entreprises, aux indépendants, aux micro-entrepreneurs et aux professions libérales touchés par la crise du coronavirus. Ce fonds sera maintenu autant que durera l’urgence sanitaire.https://web.archive.org/save/http://hauts-de-france.direccte.gouv.fr/Coronavirus-COVID-19-mouvements-sociaux-la-Direccte-vous-accompagne

Toutes les échéances de dépôt des liasses fiscales et autres déclarations assimilées du mois de mai sont ainsi décalées au 30 juin. Ces délais supplémentaires doivent permettre aux entreprises et aux experts-comptables d'accomplir leurs obligations fiscales annuelles. https://web.archive.org/save/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/france-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html; https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.economie.gouv.fr/coronavirus-FB-live-gerald-darmanin-24mars2020

Under lockdown, "travelling to work is permitted so long as the work is essential, cannot be postponed, and cannot be done from home." [https://web.archive.org/web/20200520140330/https://www.france24.com/en/20200317-france-s-coronavirus-lockdown-what-you-can-and-can-t-do]

From Tuesday 17th March 2020, seeing anyone is forbidden (except for work, food shopping, health issues and practising outdoor sports alone) hence no gatherings outside household members and coworkers  https://web.archive.org/web/20200520140330/https://www.france24.com/en/20200317-france-s-coronavirus-lockdown-what-you-can-and-can-t-do

March 17 confinement period starts, with people needing a form to leave their houses. They can leave for exercise, grocery shopping, medical appointments, judicial summons, vital family rasons.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200425104041/https://www.france24.com/en/20200327-french-pm-extends-coronavirus-lockdown-by-two-weeks-until-april-15   https://web.archive.org/save/https://data.humdata.org/dataset/acaps-covid19-government-measures-dataset
"France emposes lockdown" https://web.archive.org/web/20200420233355/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/mar/16/coronavirus-spain-takes-over-private-healthcare-amid-more-european-lockdowns

"Macron Confirms: All External & Internal Schengen Borders Will Close on Tuesday 17th March at Noon"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200425221726/https://www.schengenvisainfo.com/news/macron-confirms-all-external-internal-schengen-borders-will-close-on-tuesday-at-noon/    "March 17 :  - extraordinary European council by videoconference;  - restriction of travel to the strict minimum in the European Union;  - closure of the borders of the Schengen area;  - activation of the interministerial crisis unit by the Prime Minister."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200813100514/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19    This 'strict minimum' is:  "French citizens and their children are allowed back into the country, but foreigners are only allowed in under certain circumstances.  These are  People who have their primary residence in France. This does NOT include second home owners. Third country nationals will need to present a visa or residency card while EU nationals (which for this purpose still includes British people) do not need any proof of residency status.  People who have their permanent residency in another European country and are travelling through France to get home  Healthcare workers engaged in coronavirus-related care  Commercial good carriers such as lorry drivers and flight or cargo crews  Diplomatic staff  Cross-border workers. So for example if you live in France but work in Switzerland you will still be able to travel back and forth."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200813101145/https://www.thelocal.fr/20200407/permission-form-now-needed-for-anyone-entering-france

“An in-depth epidemiological inquiry is immediately opened in order to identify and contact everyone who has been in close contact with these patients,” France’s health ministry said, after announcing yet more confirmed cases on Feb 26 (2020).  https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.rfi.fr/en/france/20200318-france-step-up-coronavirus-new-test-methods-death-toll-climbs-covid-19-priority-risk-elderly-symptoms

France's Director General of Health Jérôme Salomon said: "We encourage the general public, if they so wish, to wear (...) these alternative masks which are being produced." Masks are not compulsory yet, but recommmended, hence 1G.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200916054944/https://www.thelocal.fr/20200406/mask-or-no-mask-what-is-the-official-coronavirus-advice-in-france

Schools start to reopen. "To meet the fears of teachers and families, the thousands of nursery and primary schools, which reopen, will be subject to a strict health protocol, to avoid any further outbreak of the epidemic." [https://web.archive.org/web/20200520143429/https://www.france24.com/fr/20200512-le-d%C3%A9confinement-continue-en-france-avec-la-r%C3%A9ouverture-des-%C3%A9coles]

Some shops are re-opening, hairdressers, beauty salons, markets to name a few: https://web.archive.org/web/20200722152406/https://www.connexionfrance.com/French-news/France-deconfinement-May-11-What-is-allowed-or-not-allowed-parks-beaches-schools-bars-restaurants-going-out-travel-transport

People who can work from home are recommended to do so. [https://web.archive.org/web/20200520113256/https://www.france24.com/en/20200429-key-points-of-france-s-strategy-for-lifting-its-nationwide-covid-19-lockdown]

After May 11, 2020, anyone with symptoms or who has been exposed to a risk of contamination will be tested.   "La doctrine scientifique fondant la stratégie nationale de dépistage virologique applicable à  compter du 11 mai 2020 consiste à dépister toute personne présentant des symptômes ou ayant  été exposée à un risque de contamination."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200524201028/https://www.gouvernement.fr/sites/default/files/rapport_jean_castex_-_preparation_de_la_sortie_du_confinement.pdf

May 11 marks the beginning of a gradual deconfinement. Monitoring of all the indicators is underway (the rate of new cases in the population over a period of seven days, the hospital capacities in intensive care remain saturated, the local system of tests and detection of contact cases is not sufficiently ready).   This phase will run until June 2.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200524220240/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/les-actions-du-gouvernement

After May 11, masks are mandatory in public transport.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200916092858/https://www.liberation.fr/direct/element/transports-en-commun-le-port-du-masque-obligatoire-a-partir-du-11-mai_112895/  Recommended indoor.

In most regions, restrictions on work have been lifted, but the government recommends working remotely wherever possible. In regions with local outbreaks, stricter policies may remain in place.     https://archive.vn/3Dxvq

Banks are asked by the government to help out their clients, provide solutions (for instance, postponing loan repayments); but since the government ensures that the population's purchasing power does not lower, there are no official measures with regards to freezing households' financial obligations households (these measures only apply to companies). https://web.archive.org/web/20200608212857/https://point-banque.fr/2020/03/20/la-banque-de-france-exclut-tout-report-des-echeances-bancaires-pour-les-particuliers/

Travel to overseas territories is limited to people who can "justify an overriding health, family or professional reason."  "On your arrival in Guadeloupe, Guyana, Reunion, Martinique, Saint-Martin, Saint-Barthélemy and Saint-Pierre-et-Miquelon, you are invited to remain isolated for 14 days, possibly in an accommodation."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200611204115/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/les-actions-du-gouvernement

President Macron has announced the reopening of nurseries, schools, and colleges in metropolitan France and overseas, starting on June 22nd.    In schools and colleges, physical distance regulations have been eased. Instead of the required 4m2 per pupil, a one-metre distance must be observed between the teacher and pupils (and between pupils themselves) in classrooms and confined spaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200713070356/https://www.vie-publique.fr/discours/274578-emmanuel-macron-14062020-covid-19

On 22nd June, the next phase of deconfiment was entered, with the whole of France being declared a "green zone" with little to no workplace closures (except for discotheques and fair grounds). Advice is as following: Working from home must be preferred whenever possible.    If you cannot work from home, staggered work patterns must be encouraged, to reduce the numbers of people both in the workplace and in public transport.    Therefore, downgraded to 1G;   https://web.archive.org/web/20200715180019/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19  https://web.archive.org/web/20200629224753/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/europe/macron-details-phase-3-of-deconfinement-in-france/1876966

True return to normal for almost all public transport in Paris and Ile-de-France. All metro stations will be open from June 22, 2020. Almost all RATP buses, tram, metro and RER are working at 100%. The same goes for the majority of Transilien SNCFs. https://web.archive.org/web/20200722155345/https://www.francebleu.fr/infos/transports/transports-en-commun-en-ile-de-france-toutes-les-stations-de-metro-seront-ouvertes-a-partir-du-22-1592483057

From June 22, the French government communicates that movements inside cities, between regions, in public transports etc. are allowed. There is no mention of 'staying at home'.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915102027/https://twitter.com/gouvernementFR/status/1276526016803020804/photo/1

Although travel to French overseas territories is more difficult and restricted, travel within metropolitan France is permitted and citizens may travel freely yet responsibly. Masks must be worn at all times. https://web.archive.org/web/20200701055822/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19

Stadiums and racing tracks may reopen to the public from 11 July. There is an upper limit of 5,000 people per venue.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200927114257/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19    However, at the request of the Council of State which had been seized, demonstrations subject to the obligation of a prior declaration are again authorized. The participants must not be more than 5,000 and must respect the sanitary rules (physical distance of at least one meter between people, systematic wearing of the mask when the respect of this distance is not guaranteed, barrier gestures).  https://web.archive.org/web/20200916095459/https://www.service-public.fr/particuliers/actualites/A14105

Since 20 July, it is compulsory for all people aged 11 and over to wear face masks in enclosed public spaces. Some local authorities (including Paris) have extended this to outdoor public spaces as well. There is a fine for not complying with these restrictions.     Since 11 May, it has been compulsory to wear masks on public transport, taxis, and private hire vehicles that do not have a plexiglass screen. Fines also apply for non-compliance.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200831205158/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/france/coronavirus

Tests are free and can be carried out without a medical prescription and on non-symptomatic patients since July 25, 2020. https://web.archive.org/web/20200915140317/https://twitter.com/MinSoliSante/status/1297149019739873280?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1297149019739873280%7Ctwgr%5Eshare_3&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.linternaute.fr%2Factualite%2Fguide-vie-quotidienne%2F2489431-test-covid-19-publics-prioritaires-tentes-de-depistage-ce-qui-va-changer%2F  "Afin de faciliter le dépistage de la Covid-19, les tests PCR sont totalement pris en charge par l'assurance maladie et ne nécessitent pas de prescription d'un médecin". https://web.archive.org/web/20200915135127/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/tests-et-depistage  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915135513/https://solidarites-sante.gouv.fr/soins-et-maladies/maladies/maladies-infectieuses/coronavirus/tout-savoir-sur-la-covid-19/article/se-faire-depister-lieux-et-conditions

Masks are still mandatory in all closed spaces  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915092101/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/masques-grand-public  and, from August 3, préfets can decide to make it mandatory at all times outside the home locally:   https://web.archive.org/web/20200915134412/https://twitter.com/JeanCASTEX/status/1290210634722729984?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw%7Ctwcamp%5Etweetembed%7Ctwterm%5E1290210634722729984%7Ctwgr%5Eshare_3&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.france24.com%2Ffr%2F20200804-quelles-sont-les-villes-de-france-oC3B9-le-masque-est-obligatoire-en-extC3A9rieur  This measure has been implemented in various cities.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915092204/https://www.leparisien.fr/societe/la-carte-des-communes-qui-imposent-le-port-du-masque-en-exterieur-02-08-2020-8362416.php

Since August 14, several departments (i.e. counties) have 'turned to red', which means that local authorities can decide on restricting activities or closing certain businesses (bars, theatres, pools, markets...). The main departments effected are: The North, the Bas-Rhin, the Seine-Maritime, the Côte-d'Or , the metropolis of Lille, Rouen, Le Havre, Strasbourg, Dijon - the two departments of Corsica (Corsica- du-Sud and Haute-Corse) and Reunion Island.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915142813/https://www.rtbf.be/info/societe/detail_france-sept-nouveaux-departements-classes-en-zone-de-circulation-active-du-coronavirus?id=10577551  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915082254/https://www.bfmtv.com/sante/covid-19-quelles-mesures-les-prefets-peuvent-ils-prendre-dans-les-zones-rouges_AV-202009130122.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915085810/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/loisirs  Remote work is no longer "the norm" but simply recommended: "Le télétravail n’est plus la norme mais peut rester une solution à privilégier en cas de circulation active du virus." https://web.archive.org/web/20200915082351/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/retour-au-travail  Night clubs have not been allowed to open throughout the period closed.

In red zones, préfets can forbid gatherings of 10 or more. The department of Bordeaux has lowered the 5000-person limit for public gatherings (that are applied nationwide) down to 1000.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915082254/https://www.bfmtv.com/sante/covid-19-quelles-mesures-les-prefets-peuvent-ils-prendre-dans-les-zones-rouges_AV-202009130122.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20200915083726/  This measure was implemented in Bordeaux on September 14.  /web/20200915083726/https://www.francebleu.fr/infos/faits-divers-justice/coronavirus-a-bordeaux-les-rassemblements-dans-l-espace-public-limites-a-10-personnes-1600089898

Since September 3, classes and schools are closed locally when Covid cases get detected. https://web.archive.org/web/20200915080853/https://www.francebleu.fr/infos/societe/covid-19-deux-premieres-classes-fermees-a-paris-apres-un-cas-de-contamination-1599150031

From Tuesday 22 September, 2020, classes are no longer being closed if only one or two pupils has been tested positive. Their classmates and teachers are no longer considered as "contact cases". This measure aims at diminishing the frequency of schools closing  /web/20200923080458/https://www.20minutes.fr/sante/2866611-20200921-coronavirus-partir-mardi-protocole-sanitaire-allege-ecoles

In regions on maximum alert then there are no large public gatherings allowed.    "In the enhanced alert zones, gatherings are now limited to no more than 10 people, and bars will be compelled to close at 10:00 p.m. starting from Monday. Local and student parties will be prohibited and conference rooms and multi-purpose rooms will also be closed."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200926094132/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/europe/france-to-roll-out-new-measures-as-covid-19-surges/1983688

Limitation of the public for major events to 1,000 people (instead of 5,000) or to 50% of the capacity if this is less than 1,000 people, in addition to a ban on marquee events. Despite this, generally gatherings of more than 10 people are banned.  https://archive.vn/ve2A3#selection-1897.0-1915.22

According to the government’s covid 19 website: “Within metropolitan France, you may travel freely. You must wear a mask at all times on public transport.”    https://archive.vn/GmKNQ#selection-367.0-369.79    Cannot find any advice to not travel within France and to avoid certain areas.  https://archive.vn/HpAft

According to French government website and IMF website, postponement of rent and utility payments only apply to microenterprises and SMEs.   Cannot find any information about debt or contract relief specific to households.  https://archive.vn/NWam2  https://archive.vn/nyT1l#selection-9613.928-9613.1016

Since Saturday 17th October local curfews will be imposed in the Paris region and 8 more cities : Grenoble, Lille, Lyon, Aix-Marseille, Saint-Etienne, Rouen, Montpellier and Toulouse for at least 4 weeks from 9 PM to 6 AM    https://archive.vn/GmKNQ#selection-285.81-285.301

France entered a new national lockdown on Friday 30 October. Schools and creches will remain open with social-distancing measures in place, but universities nationwide will be shut with online learning will be carried out.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201102183825/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19

France entered a new national lockdown on Friday 30 October. People are allowed to leave their home only to go to work (if they cannot work from home).     https://web.archive.org/web/20201102182651/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/france/coronavirus
Public gatherings are banned.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201102183825/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19

Social gatherings are banned. Everyone found outside has to carry a written statement justifying their journey.   'Places of worship may remain open for weddings (with a maximum of six people) and funerals (with a maximum of 30 people).'    https://web.archive.org/web/20201102183825/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19

People are allowed to leave their home only to go to work (if they cannot work from home), to buy essential goods, seek medical help or to exercise for one hour a day. Everyone found outside has to carry a written statement justifying their journey.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201102183825/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19

Travel between different parts of France is not allowed. Internal European borders will remain open but external borders are closed except for essential travel. All travelers arriving in France will be tested at airports and ports.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201102183825/https://www.gouvernement.fr/en/coronavirus-covid-19

Gradual re-opening.   Shops and services, including public libraries, are now open.    Bars, restaurants, cinemas, theatres, museums and gyms remain closed.    https://archive.vn/ZpG77#selection-471.1-475.70

4. March 2020, Ministry of Health confirmed first case of covid-19 in Faroe Islands.    Returning travelers from high risk areas, including China, Iran, South Korea and parts of Northern Italy are recommended to stay at home for 14 days in order to eliminate the risk of spread.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122094903/https://corona.fo/news/59/first-case-of-covid-19-confirmed-in-faroe-islands?_l=en

12th March 2020, The government has advised people working in the public sector to work from home if possible. The Faroese parliament will remain closed for the next two weeks.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122102627/http://local.fo/the-country-slows-down-schools-daycares-and-parliament-affected/

12th March 2020, the Faroese Confederation of Sports & Olympic Committee advised sports clubs and associations to put competitions, training sessions, matches and other events on hold for the next couple of weeks, and several clubs have already agreed to do so. Many cultural events have also been cancelled or postponed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122102627/http://local.fo/the-country-slows-down-schools-daycares-and-parliament-affected/

12th March 2020, all indoor events with more than 100 participants should be cancelled, and all bars and nightclubs are asked to close at 10pm.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122101124/http://kvf.fo/greinar/2020/03/12/schools-closing-down-monday

17th March 2020, Temporary border control on entry to the Faroe Islands from abroad is established with a view to curb entry to the Danish realm of foreign citizens without a worthy purpose. This measure has been taken in order to prevent the spreading of COVID-19. Anyone travelling to the Faroe Islands must be prepared to produce an identification document.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122111542/https://corona.fo/news/93/temporary-border-control-on-entry-to-the-faroe-islands-from-abroad?_l=en

15th March 2020, Due to the Covid-19 decease there will be an altered sailing plan on route 7 and route 60 from March 17th until March 30th.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.ssl.fo/en/news/altered-sailing-plans-from-march-17th/

15th March 2020, The remuneration structure applies to all Faroese companies, some in the period 31 March to 30 June 2020 have at least a 50 per cent decline in sales combined with the same period last year. Fishing, aling, fisheries, etc. are not covered by the order.    Treytir fyri at fáa remuneration is, among other things, that the companies will not pay out the prize money for the next three years, and that a joint exhibition for managers and management members is not more than 600,000 ISK. this year.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201208091337/https://corona.fo/user_login?_redirect=%2Fhjalparpakki2%3F_l%3Den

Before business resumed on Monday, the Faroese government announced four ways they would help businesses get through this crisis.[40]    1)The government will pay companies back the salary of people who have been asked by the government to be in quarantine. People who can work from home are not covered.  2) If companies need to decrease the amount of hours their employees work, the Faroese Employment Office will provide the lost income at a percentage of the maximum payment.  3) Companies can pay their VAT 3 months late.  4) The Danish Growth Fund can assist small and medium-sized companies with financing of operations.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208091337/https://corona.fo/user_login?_redirect=%2Fhjalparpakki2%3F_l%3Den
16th March 2020, all schools and day-care centres are shut down.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122101124/http://kvf.fo/greinar/2020/03/12/schools-closing-down-monday

23rd March 2020, Currently, over 2.200 tests have been conducted in the Faroe Islands. Tests are conducted at the hospitals in the Faroe Islands, and the samples are examined by the Faroese Food and Veterinary Authority.  The Faroe Islands seem to hold the record for most tests conducted per million inhabitants – at least compared to Scandinavia and other countries, which have a high amount of cases, statistics from the website Our World in Data reveal.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201113034623/http://local.fo/covid-19-the-faroe-islands-conduct-the-most-tests/

24th March 2020, Workplaces directly related to the coronavirus outbreak are allowed to make exceptions to the rules about resting time for staff.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201207135121/http://kvf.fo/greinar/2020/03/24/deviations-working-time-regulations

29th March 2020, The epidemic commission recommends that only permanent residents should travel to the Faroes for Easter, and all incoming passengers should self-quarantine for 14 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/2/http://kvf.fo/greinar/2020/03/29/non-essential-air-travel-discouraged-over-easter.

29th March 2020,  In an effort to clarify some possible misconceptions, KvF asked Chief Medical Officer Lars Fodgaard Møller to clarify some common concerns about the coronavirus.  KvF TV news programme Dagur og Vika asked viewers to submit questions about the virus.    https://web.archive.org/save/http://kvf.fo/greinar/2020/03/29/busting-corona-myths-top-doctor

31st March 2020, Although most institutions have closed down amid the corona lockdown, there are numerous phone helplines that can offer support and advice.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201207225036/https://corona.fo/news/242/help-is-only-a-phone-call-away?_l=en

10th April 2020, Special corona strategy saves lives  The Faroese strategy has placed a strong focus on suppression, with world record high test numbers relative to the population as a means of suppressing the virus entirely by trying to catch cases early and trace all contacts.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208075454/http://kvf.fo/greinar/2020/04/10/special-corona-strategy-saves-lives

20th April 2020,   Preschool and grades 1 to 3 will return to normal classes from Monday 20 April 2020.    Classes are voluntary. There will be organized teaching but attendance will not be compulsory, so that parents who so wish and have the possibility, can keep their children at home.     Afterschool recreation centers will also reopen from Monday 20 April 2020.    Grades 4 to 10 will continue to have classes from home. Pupils in grades 9 and 10 will not have final exams in the summer.    For the final year of high school, some classes will resume on school premises from Monday 20 April 2020.    Final exams for the graduating high school year are under consideration and will be adapted to circumstances.    Classes for other high school years will continue to take place remotely.    Vocational classes at the Technical College in Klaksvík and Glasir in Tórshavn will resume from Monday 20 April 2020.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201208110250/https://corona.fo/news/308/easing-restrictions?_l=en

20th April 2020,   Work in the public sector shall continue as usual, to the extent this is possible. This means that services for citizens and businesses should be provided as usual, while adhering to the guidelines for preventing infection. As far as possible, employees in the public sector who can work from home should continue to do so.  Some parts of the private sector will begin to increase their activities. As they do, it remains vitally important that all official guidelines for measures to prevent the spread of the coronavirus continue to be followed closely.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208110250/https://corona.fo/news/308/easing-restrictions?_l=en

1st May 2020, SSL busses will service all routes, although with a reduced schedule. The priority will be to ensure that people can get to and from work in the morning and afternoon.   Ferries are currently operating with a reduced schedule. From 1 May the ferry to Mykines will resume.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208105658/https://corona.fo/news/378/reopening-faroese-society-phase-2?_l=en

The Government proposes the following changes:    · Grade 4 starts back at school on 4 May    · Grade 5 starts back at school on 11 May    · Grade 9 starts back at school on 18 May    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208105658/https://corona.fo/news/378/reopening-faroese-society-phase-2?_l=en

4th May 2020, No festivals or larger cultural events should be held before 30 June. The situation will be assessed and a new announcement made towards the end of May.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208105658/https://corona.fo/news/378/reopening-faroese-society-phase-2?_l=en

From 4 May, a maximum of 50 people can gather in one place. A personal distance of 2 meters should be maintained. Restaurants, bars and dance venues can reopen in adherence to the public health guidelines. They should continue to close no later than 22:00.    With an increase in the recommended maximum number of people at any one gathering, churches and congregations can resume their activities in adherence to the public health guidelines.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208105658/https://corona.fo/news/378/reopening-faroese-society-phase-2?_l=en

Sporting events can resume from Saturday 9 May under controlled conditions. To begin with, it is recommended that both indoor winter sports and outdoor summer sports are played without spectators.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208105658/https://corona.fo/news/378/reopening-faroese-society-phase-2?_l=en

On Thursday 14 May 2020, the Government of the Faroe Islands announced the third phase in the reopening of Faroese society.  All levels of primary and secondary school will return to school. This means that pupils in grades 6, 7, 8 and 10 should return to school as soon as possible. The University of the Faroe Islands, the Centre of Maritime Studies and Engineering and colleges can also resume normal activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208121019/https://corona.fo/news/431/reopening-faroese-society-phase-3?_l=en

14th May 2020, The recommendation remains that no festivals or larger cultural events should be held before 30 June. The situation will be assessed and a new announcement made towards the end of May.  Spectators can now attend rowing races, football matches and other sporting events, but under conditions designed to minimise the risk of infection.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208121019/https://corona.fo/news/431/reopening-faroese-society-phase-3?_l=en

People can now gather in groups of up to 100, while also maintaining the recommended physical distance.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208121019/https://corona.fo/news/431/reopening-faroese-society-phase-3?_l=en

SSL buses will now resume their normal schedule on all routes, with no requirement for prior booking. Some restrictions will still apply. A maximum of 22 passengers can travel with the larger buses, 10 with the medium size buses and 5 with people with the small buses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208121019/https://corona.fo/news/431/reopening-faroese-society-phase-3?_l=en

Tourists continue to be urged not to travel to the Faroe Islands before 30 June. All people arriving in the Faroe Islands should self-quarantine for 14 days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208121019/https://corona.fo/news/431/reopening-faroese-society-phase-3?_l=en

From Saturday 27 June,  As travel will be opened up between the Faroe Islands and a larger number of countries, all people travelling to the Faroe Islands must be tested for COVID-19. This requirement also applies to Faroese citizens and residents who have been travelling abroad.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201208132224/https://corona.fo/news/486/all-travellers-must-now-be-tested?_l=en

20th July 2020, All passengers must wear face masks when travelling from the airport on our bus route 300 and possible further travel with one of our busses and ferries.     Face masks can be purchased at the information centre at the airport.    Passengers without face masks will not be allowed on board.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201208094725/https://www.ssl.fo/en/news/mandatory-face-masks/

5th Aug 2020, A new and aggressive testing strategy forms the basis of the new plan to prevent further spread of Covid-19. All mass events should be cancelled or postponed, and nightlife establishments are encouraged to close until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208133915/http://kvf.fo/greinar/2020/08/05/new-covid-19-preventive-measures

5th Aug 2020, A new and aggressive testing strategy forms the basis of the new plan to prevent further spread of Covid-19. The use of protective face masks is recommended in crowded places. - People are urged to take the social distancing and hygiene guidelines seriously.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208133915/http://kvf.fo/greinar/2020/08/05/new-covid-19-preventive-measures
8th Sept 2020, Masks no longer a requirement.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201020232057/https://local.fo/hospitals-open-to-visitors-again-masks-no-longer-a-requirement/

13th Nov 2020, The Government tightens border controls and travel advice. Anyone travelling to the Faroe Islands should provide evidence of a negative COVID-19 test which has been taken no more than three days before departure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208142327/https://corona.fo/news/704/the-government-tightens-border-controls-and-travel-advice?_l=en    https://web.archive.org/web/20201208142611/https://corona.fo/news/706/new-recommendations-in-effect-from-13-november-and-for-the-rest-of-the-year?_l=en

The first report of coronavirus appeared on the Gabonese governments website was published on 22 January 2020. Regular press releases appear as available pdfs on Ministry of Health website since then.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200622140821/http://www.gouvernement.ga/5-conseil-des-ministres/3638-annee-2020/3639-une-epidemie-dune-nouvelle-souche-de-virus-appartenant-a-la-famille-des-coronavirus/

"However, in view of the spread of this epidemic beyond the epicenter, the Government has decided to raise the level of surveillance and to suspend, until further notice, access to the national territory for any passenger coming from from China" [https://web.archive.org/web/20200622133958/http://www.gouvernement.ga/3467-gouvernement/3657-communique-du-gouvernement-relatif-aux-mesures-de-vigilance-sanitaire-aux-aeroports-et-ports/]

According to UNICEF situation overview Gabon has been testing symptomatic patients since March 12th. However, as of April 24 testing scope broaden to general availability albeit lagging in results. https://reliefweb.int/report/gabon/unicef-gabon-covid-19-situation-report-02-reporting-period-15-30-april

An announcement of measures by President Ali Bongo on 13 March included banning of all gatherings of more than 50 people and the suspension of national sporting and public cultural events. https://web.archive.org/web/20200622132115/https://gabonactu.com/coronavirus-declaration-tres-dure-du-gabon-pour-eviter-la-propagation-du-virus/

An announcement of measures by President Ali Bongo on 13 March included banning of all gatherings of more than 50 people and the suspension of national sporting and public cultural events. https://web.archive.org/web/20200622132115/https://gabonactu.com/coronavirus-declaration-tres-dure-du-gabon-pour-eviter-la-propagation-du-virus/

"Gabon on Friday adopted measures to combat the new coronavirus, including the closure of schools for two weeks and a halt to the granting of tourist visas for areas affected by the pandemic. Some businesses (e.g. motels, clubs, bars) closed,  some nonessential (e.g. hair salons) restricted to one customer at a time but allowed to remain open, others exempt from customer limits but asked to keep 1m between people (e.g. grocery stores)   https://web.archive.org/web/20200417074718/http://www.gabonactu.com/declaration-integrale-sur-la-fermeture-des-frontieres-au-gabon/

Government announced measures restricting all the public and private gatherings to not more than 10 people.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200417074718/http://www.gabonactu.com/declaration-integrale-sur-la-fermeture-des-frontieres-au-gabon/

On March 20 and 21, the Gabonese government announced a number of new measures aimed at reducing the spread of COVID-19. These measures include a countrywide curfew.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200622131619/https://ga.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"Dr. Guy Patrick Obiang Ndong announced that from Monday, March 30, health personnel will screen all contact cases." https://web.archive.org/web/20200417082047/https://www.gabonreview.com/gabon-tous-les-cas-contacts-seront-depistes-au-covid-19/

The government is drafting legislation to adjust spending plans. OPEC’s second-smallest member secured $147 million from the International Monetary Fund on Friday to support its efforts to contain the virus and the economic damage it causes. President Ali Bongo Ondimba said an "exceptional massive aid" package of FCFA 250 billion ($415 million) had been set up to help both individuals and businesses who have been hard hit by the coronavirus pandemic.  He said the state will inject FCFA 225 million will be used to help companies while FCFA 6 billion ($10 million) will be dedicated to monthly payment of electricity and water bills for the "most fragile and economically weak" Gabonese.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200622142711/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2020-04-11/gabon-declares-state-of-emergency-over-covid-19-revises-outlook

On April 10, authorities announced the implementation of a 15-day lockdown in the capital Libreville, and the nearby communes of Owendo, Akanda, Ntoum, and Pointe Denis as of Monday, April 13. As such, residents are only permitted to leave their homes for limited reasons, such as obtaining essential goods or seeking healthcare.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200426174033/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/332106/gabon-authorities-implement-15-day-lockdown-in-libreville-april-13-update-5

On April 10, authorities announced the implementation of a 15-day lockdown in the capital Libreville, and the nearby communes of Owendo, Akanda, Ntoum, and Pointe Denis as of Monday, April 13. Individuals are not allowed to leave the lockdown regions. Further travel within the Grande Libreville area and across Gabon has been restricted.  Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20200426174033/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/332106/gabon-authorities-implement-15-day-lockdown-in-libreville-april-13-update-5  https://web.archive.org/web/20200426175024/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/coronavirus

On April 10, the Gabonese government announced a 15-day period of confinement for Libreville, Owendo, Akanda, Ntoum, and Pointe Dénis.  The period of confinement began at midnight on April 12 and may be extended as necessary.  All U.S. citizens who reside in the areas listed should prepare to remain at home for an extended period.  As of April 15, individuals in all parts of the country are required to wear masks in public to limit the spread of COVID-19.  During the period of confinement, residents may leave their homes only to perform necessary tasks such as securing food, water, or medicine or if their job involves performing a service that the government has deemed essential.  Individuals should remain in their own communes when they leave their homes to procure essential goods.  Supermarkets, stores that sell food, and pharmacies will remain open. Persons who must leave their homes to provide essential services must obtain a laissez-passer from the Ministry of Interior.  Law enforcement and military officials will monitor compliance with the confinement measures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200428035829/https://ga.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/coronavirus-update/
On Monday 13 April Gabon has extended its lock-down from specific cities to nationwide. https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.africanews.com/2020/04/14/covid-19-gabon-begins-lockdown//

According to UNICEF situation overview Gabon has been testing symptomatic patients since March 12th. However, as of April 24 testing scope broaden to general availability albeit lagging in results. https://reliefweb.int/report/gabon/unicef-gabon-covid-19-situation-report-02-reporting-period-15-30-april

"On April 27, the Gabonese government announced the following modifications to previously enacted confinement measures:    - Companies should continue to encourage telework for employees but may gradually return to business and administrative activities. Work hours must be limited to 7:30 am to 2:00 pm.  Health control devices such as thermoflash devices, hand sanitizer, and masks must be placed at company and administrative office entrances.  - Small businesses such as hair salons, garages, tire repair ships, and artisan workshops may begin to reopen subject to social distancing measures such as reductions in the numbers of staff and clients, the presence of disinfectants, and the wearing of masks.  - Other commercial enterprises such as hardware stores, building and construction entities, and retailers of office supplies, furniture, and appliances, will gradually reopen with social distancing measures in place.  - Bars, restaurants, and hotels will remain closed until further notice."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200622131619/https://ga.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"There is no change in the restriction’s measures since May the 11th when the Government  ended the State of Emergency and relaxed some of the lockdown constraints while  maintaining and enforcing strict social distancing guidelines with compulsory mask  wearing along all the other prevention actions, school shutdown and the ban of  commercial flights and interprovincial traveling. However, With the lockdown relaxed in  greater Libreville area, compliance with rules on social distancing and use of facemasks  is inadequate."  https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Gabon%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20%E2%80%93%20%2304%20Reporting%20period%20-%2017-28%20May%202020.pdf    Still a 6pm-6am nationwide curfew.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200622131034/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/staying-during-coronavirus
The State of Emergency will be lifted from midnight on 11 May. Restrictions on travel within the Grande Libreville area have been lifted. Travel outside Libreville to inland Gabon remains restricted.

Start of publishing Facebook videos/graphics to spread awareness of health measures to take.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200622141442/https://www.facebook.com/PresidenceGabon/videos/272794397185865/

Flight restrictions have eased to allow three flights per airline, per week. Land and sea borders are closed.    On arrival, all passengers must take a compulsory test for COVID-19 at Libreville Airport. Passengers are then required to self-isolate for 48 hours whilst the COVID-19 test is being processed. If the COVID-19 test is negative, passengers will be issued a test certificate, which is valid for 14 days and can be renewed at the end of this period after another test is undertaken.    If a COVID-19 test taken at the airport is positive, then passengers are required to continue self-isolation and await specific instructions from Gabonese health authorities. All COVID-19 tests taken in Gabon supersede any that were taken before arrival in Gabon.    I would not consider this a ban as long as flights are still permitted.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201123164426/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/gabon/entry-requirements

With Wales and England limiting meetings or gatherings indoors even within your extended household to 6 people (not including any children aged under 11 in Wales) on September 14, all areas of the UK (England, Wales, Scotland, Northern Ireland) have gathering restrictions that rise to a 4 in the coding. Therefore, the coding is upgraded to 4G on review.   It should be noted, however, that technically not ALL private gatherings are reduced to a level 4 due to Wales allowing outdoor gatherings of slightly bigger groups. On rainy days, of which Wales has a considerable amount, outdoor gatherings outside of someones gardens (for which the rule of six applies even outside) are somewhat unlikely and a coding of 4 is therefore appropriate. https://web.archive.org/web/20201004213732/https://gov.wales/guidance-leaving-your-home-and-seeing-other-people-coronavirus (Wales) https://web.archive.org/web/20201004214002/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-51506729 (England) https://web.archive.org/web/20201004214404/https://www.irishpost.com/news/rule-of-six-how-todays-new-social-gathering-restrictions-affect-you-192812 (NI) (Scotland in previous sources)

From 14 September, the Welsh government effectively required face coverings in *ALL indoor public places*, for both customers and staff working in those indoor public areas. This includes a very wide range of locations, such as shops and shopping centres, places of worship, hairdressers and salons, cinemas and museums, gyms and leisure centres, and anywhere that is open to members of the public. It would also include any public areas within buildings that are otherwise closed to the public – for example a reception area of an office building.    The only indoor public areas where face coverings will not be required are where you are inside a place to eat or drink, for example, cafés, restaurants and pubs - but only for the purpose of eating or drinking.     Since all nations of the UK now have a 2 in place, upgraded to 2G (see subnational coding).  https://web.archive.org/web/20201003210731/https://gov.wales/face-coverings-guidance-public

On the 22nd of September, the British government, in the grip of a second wave of coronavirus,  told the nation’s workers to work from home if they could, a policy reversal that forced banks and other employers to readjust their corporate policies on the fly.  “We are once again asking office workers who can work from home to do so,” Prime Minister Boris Johnson said on Tuesday, adding that Britain had reached “a perilous turning point” as nearly 5,000 new coronavirus cases were reported the same day.  Scottish, Northern Ireland, and Wales governments all were advising that where possible, people should work from home prior (hence 0 is likely wrong for previous codings as the change coding to 0 was referring to the Leicester case and ignored Scottish advise that originally prompted the 1T coding).   https://web.archive.org/web/20201004232124/https://www.nytimes.com/live/2020/09/22/business/stock-market-today-coronavirus  https://www.instituteforgovernment.org.uk/explainers/coronavirus-lockdown-rules-four-nations-uk (not archivable, summary for Scotland/Wales/NI governments)

As part of the newly introduced policies, this is recommended in very high levels areas, but not in high or medium levels.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201012181705/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/prime-minister-announces-new-local-covid-alert-levels

As part of the newly introduced policies, this is recommended in very high and high levels areas, but not in medium levels.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201012181705/https://www.gov.uk/government/news/prime-minister-announces-new-local-covid-alert-levels
In Northern Ireland, all schools must close as of October 19, and will not reopen until November 2.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201015054422/https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-northern-ireland-53007269

Restrictions on socialising are in place across the UK, and yet all 3 tiers of policy still allow at least some forms of nonessential activity (tier 3 still permits weddings, dining out, sport, religious services). As such, the  policy seems to be best characterised as a general restriction on social and public activity while not actually recommending 'staying at home'.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201030131830/https://www.gov.uk/guidance/local-covid-alert-levels-what-you-need-to-know

On Friday 23rd October the Welsh Government introduced a fortnight-long firebreak lockdown meaning you should only leave your home for very limited reasons.  When you leave home, you should try to minimise time spent outside of the home and ensure you stay at least 2 meters away from anyone outside your household.  See Government website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201101102331/https://gov.wales/coronavirus-firebreak-frequently-asked-question

On Friday 23rd October the Welsh Government introduced a fortnight-long firebreak lockdown meaning travel is limited to essential travel only, such as, work purposes where people cannot work from home. Travelling within Wales for holiday and visiting friends/family is not permitted  See Government website, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201101102331/https://gov.wales/coronavirus-firebreak-frequently-asked-questions
All but essential services closed in Wales.     https://archive.vn/W8OGB

The government once again urged citizens to adhere to the restrictions imposed as a result of the state of emergency, to remain at home, and to refrain from going out unless there is an emergency. Otherwise, measures envisaged by law will be used in response: http://archive.vn/MZRJf

"We have decided to significantly tighten measures within the framework of the state of emergency. Effectively - and I would like to emphasize this - effectively, we are declaring universal quarantine, which will begin on 31 March, at 8:00 in the morning. This quarantine means the following:    • It is completely forbidden to travel using any type of public transport (including the subway), both within and between cities and municipalities.    • It is only permissible to travel using light vehicles (including taxis), and only if the recommendation of the Ministry of Healthcare has been taken into consideration, i.e., if there are no more than three persons in an automobile, with the essential condition that the two persons are seated in the rear seat: http://archive.vn/YrnnM#selection-2433.8-2448.0

Giorgi Gakharia: We Have Decided To Significantly Tighten Measures Under State of Emergency, Effectively Declaring Universal Quarantine:   - a full quarantine will be declared for the duration of the state of emergency. It will be forbidden to move on foot or using any other mode of transportation in the cities and throughout the entire country between the hours of 21:00 and 06:00. Effectively - and I would like to emphasize this once again - effectively, this means that a so-called curfew is being declared throughout the entire country between the hours of 21:00 and 06:00.    • Checkpoints will be set up in the cities of Tbilisi, Batumi, Kutaisi, Rustavi, Poti, Zugdidi, and Gori in order to control the movement of individuals, to check their health status, and to ensure the fulfillment of the tightened measures under the state of emergency, as well as to provide initial thermal screening and to control the administrative borders of these cities. These measures will be carried out by the forces of the Ministry of Internal Affairs, with the involvement of the relevant agencies of the Ministry of Defense: http://archive.vn/YrnnM#selection-2433.8-2448.0

"We have decided to significantly tighten measures within the framework of the state of emergency. From June 17, according to Irakli Chikovani - Advisor to the Prime Minister of Georgia – the wearing of medical masks will be mandatory in closed public spaces.   Link: https://archive.vn/bLZHs

"All hired employees who officially worked and lost their jobs, income during the crisis after the declaration of the state of emergency and cannot receive their salaries, will receive assistance from the state in the amount of 1200 GEL over a period of six months. This means that these people will receive 200 GEL per month" - Prime Minister. "In addition, the same kind of subsidy will be received for the salary of 750 GEL for all retained jobs and remuneration will be up to 1500 GEL. In fact, in this way we are assisting both the citizens of Georgia to retain their jobs salaries and the entrepreneurs to retain the jobs. The budget of this event is 250 million GEL", said Giorgi Gakharia: http://archive.vn/28a9Y

An automatic VAT refund mechanism will be implemented, which means that as soon as an entrepreneur has an excess on his/her personal account, he/she will automatically be refunded VAT, without any demand. In addition, this year additional 600 million GEL will be returned from the budget in the form of VAT during one year. These two events jointly are crucial for companies and entrepreneurs in maintaining liquidity", said the Prime Minister: http://archive.vn/28a9Y

In line with a plan developed by the Government of Georgia, first phase of reduced restrictions and re-opening of the economy started.  All types of online trade - both wholesale and retail - are permitted from today. Also, delivery service of any commodity is fully allowed from today and open-air fruit and vegetable markets also resume operation: http://archive.vn/nsT6z

The Interagency Coordination Council led by the Prime Minister has made a decision to terminate the state of emergency, effective May 23. Accordingly, the curfew is also terminated. Still, given the epidemiological situation-as the virus is still here to force us to take active steps to stop the spread of COVID-19-it is of utmost importance to apply certain regulations in the country to ensure against risking the ultimate value of our citizens' safety, lives, and health.    Schools and universities must continue the education process using various forms of remote teaching/communication.    However, conducting practical / laboratory work or holding examinations non-remotely in universities (in accordance with the recommendations issued by the Ministry of Healthcare) has become permissible. Coded from 3G to 3T due to this allowance.     Link: http://archive.vn/Ck7Xg#selection-2207.2-2207.195

he Interagency Coordination Council led by the Prime Minister has made a decision to terminate the state of emergency, effective May 23, that is, tonight after midnight. Another session of the Interagency Coordination Council was held under the leadership of Prime Minister of Georgia Giorgi Gakharia.    Members of the council discussed the next stage of the lifting of restrictions, which came into force today. Namely, all types of open shops, trade centers, open-air and enclosed markets, and restaurants with outdoor spaces have reopened for business. Furthermore, public transport resumed operation on 29 May. It was stressed that all decisions pertaining to the lifting of restrictions were made having taken into account the social and economic interests of citizens; however, it is essential to follow the relevant rules and recommendations, including those on social distancing and the use of face masks, in order to avoid the risk of spreading the virus. Relevant agencies will periodically monitor the enforcement of preventive measures and established standards.    Council members also discussed the upcoming stage of the lifting of restrictions, which will come into force on 8 June and will include the opening of all types of restaurants, the resumption of intercity transportation, and the reopening of the hotels that have passed the inspection of the Labor Inspection of the Ministry of Healthcare and have received the appropriate permits. The inspection of hotels has already started and will actively continue.    At this stage, Tetritskaro and two villages in Bolnisi Municipality - Mushevani and Geta - remain under strict quarantine.     Link: http://archive.vn/uAZ1W
