Many schools have moved to distance learning.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201106191444/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/

Public transportation is operating. Taxis are limited to three people in the vehicle: a driver and two backseat passengers.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201106191444/https://ge.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-on-georgia/

The Government of Georgia imposed movement restrictions in major cities between 10 PM and 5 AM. During the restricted time, public and private transportation (including walking) is not permitted, unless it is for an essential need.  Link: https://archive.fo/kYCaw

Any and all types of conferences, training sessions, cultural or entertainment events are restricted. Only virtual formats will be permitted online.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130172338/https://www.stopcov.ge/en/shezgudvebi

Regular inter-city passenger transportation, including that of by rail, bus or minibus are restricted. Restriction does not apply to light vehicles (including taxis).     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130172338/https://www.stopcov.ge/en/shezgudvebi

Municipal transport will be suspended within Tbilisi, Telavi, Batumi, Kutaisi, Rustavi, Gori. Poti and Zugdidi. Mobility of people walking or driving restricted across Georgia, as well as staying in a public space from 21:00 to 05:00; exceptions will be made for the New Year's Eve on December 31 and Orthodox Christmas on January 6.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130172338/https://www.stopcov.ge/en/shezgudvebi
https://web.archive.org/web/20200406234333/https://www.graphic.com.gh/news/general-news/health-ministry-widens-coronavirus-screening-at-kotoka-airport.html

On the 11th of March 2020, the President of Ghana's first speech about the COVID-19 pandemic included stating that the Ministry of Information would be tasked to lead an educational campaign -https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gbcghanaonline.com/featured/coronavirus-govt-sets-aside-100-million-to-enhance-preparedness-and-response-in-ghana/2020/
/web/20200407003532/https://www.theghanareport.com/coronavirus-contact-tracing-increases-to-600-health-minister/
A coordinated public informational campaign through this webpage. https://web.archive.org/web/20200315001922/https://ghanahealthservice.org/covid19/
Excerpts from the President's speech noting school closures at all levels:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200406205622/https://www.instagram.com/p/B9xX3p0HCAZ/

" All public gatherings, including conferences, workshops, funerals, festivals, political rallies, sporting events and religious activities, such as services in churches and mosques, have been suspended for the next four (4) weeks. Private burials are permitted, but with limited numbers, not exceeding twenty-five (25) in attendance"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200510225459/https://www.moh.gov.gh/president-akufo-addo-addresses-nation-on-measures-taken-by-govt-to-combat-the-coronavirus-pandemic/

" All public gatherings, including conferences, workshops, funerals, festivals, political rallies, sporting events and religious activities, such as services in churches and mosques, have been suspended for the next four (4) weeks. Private burials are permitted, but with limited numbers, not exceeding twenty-five (25) in attendance"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200510225459/https://www.moh.gov.gh/president-akufo-addo-addresses-nation-on-measures-taken-by-govt-to-combat-the-coronavirus-pandemic/

Starting on March 17, Ghana banned entry to anyone who has been to a country with more than 200 coronavirus cases in the previous 14 days, unless they were official residents or Ghanaian nationals.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200408132720/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/03/coronavirus-travel-restrictions-border-shutdowns-country-200318091505922.html; Non-Ghanaian travellers and non-residents from high risk regions  banned - https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.instagram.com/p/B9wfz-JpQqb/
http://moi.gov.gh/president-akufo-addo-addresses-nation-on-updates-to-ghanas-enhanced-response-to-the-coronavirus-pandemic/ https://twitter.com/moigovgh/status/1239197635006943235/photo/1

In his address, the president said that "all persons that have come in contact with infected persons [will be] tested for the virus" http://web.archive.org/web/20200518210434/https://twitter.com/moigovgh/status/1241474156891459586/photo/1

Ghana Bans borders since March 22; https://web.archive.org/web/20200425193227/https://newsghana.com.gh/covid-19-akufo-addo-extends-border-closure-by-two-weeks/; https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/03/coronavirus-travel-restrictions-border-shutdowns-country-200318091505922.html

As part of the lockdown measures, the president stated that only individuals and institutions providing the following services shall be exempted from the restrictions: Individuals and institutions providing the following services shall be exempted from the restrictions: i Members of the Executive, Legislature and the Judiciary; ii production, distribution and marketing of food, beverages, pharmaceuticals, medicine, paper and plastic packages; iii environmental and sanitation activities; iv staff of VALCO; v road and railway construction workers; vi mining workers; vii fisherfolk; viii members of the security agencies assigned lawful duties; ix staff of electricity, water, telecommunications, e-commerce and digital service providers; and x staff of fuel stations.  "So, effective 1am on Monday, 30th March, some forty-eight hours from now, I have imposed, pursuant to the powers granted the President of the Republic, under the Imposition of Restrictions Act, 2020 (Act 1012), restrictions on movement of persons in the Greater Accra Metropolitan Area (GAMA, which includes Awutu Senya East), and the Greater Kumasi Metropolitan Area and contiguous districts, for a period of two (2) weeks, subject to review."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200416210042/http://www.presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1545-address-to-the-nation-by-president-of-the-republic-nana-addo-dankwa-akufo-addo-on-updates-to-ghana-s-enhanced-response-to-the-coronavirus-pandemic-on-friday-27th-march-2020

Ghana does not have a formal public transport system persay. Rather, the public depend on private companies to provide public transportation. As such, Once the lockdown was announced, the president in his speech added" there shall be in this period, no inter-city movement of vehicles and aircrafts for private or commerical purposes for the areas of restrictive measures, except for vehicles nad aircrafts providing essential services and those carrying cargo" https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.facebook.com/moi.gov.gh/photos/a.1279963482038815/2816321835069631/?type=3&theater    Evidence here that the transport ban affected state owned transport companies > https://web.archive.org/save/https://newsghana.com.gh/accra-tema-bound-commercial-vehicles-grounded-in-ho/    Evidence here that some state owned transport buses which were initially halted after lockdown directive, were to be made available to provide essential services > https://web.archive.org/web/20200416204557/http://vimnewsgh.com/ayalolo-buses-to-receive-govt-support-to-run-again-after-halting-services-due-covid-19-social-distancing-directive/
From March 30, with the lockdowns of Accra and Kumansi regions, residents are advised to stay at home, and only to go out for essentials.   http://archive.fo/wip/GBJRT

"This, in essence, means that everyone resident in these areas must stay at home for the next two weeks. However, if you must go out, it must only be to get essential items such as food, medicine, water, undertake banking transactions, or to use public toilet facilities. But, as much as possible, stay at home.  So, effective 1am on Monday, 30th March, some forty-eight hours from now, I have imposed, pursuant to the powers granted the President of the Republic, under the Imposition of Restrictions Act, 2020 (Act 1012), restrictions on movement of persons in the Greater Accra Metropolitan Area (GAMA, which includes Awutu Senya East), and the Greater Kumasi Metropolitan Area and contiguous districts, for a period of two (2) weeks, subject to review...    There shall be, during this period, no inter-city movement of vehicles and aircrafts for private or commercial purposes for the areas of the restrictive measures, except for vehicles and aircrafts providing essential services and those carrying cargo."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200416210042/http://www.presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1545-address-to-the-nation-by-president-of-the-republic-nana-addo-dankwa-akufo-addo-on-updates-to-ghana-s-enhanced-response-to-the-coronavirus-pandemic-on-friday-27th-march-2020

Government will absorb the water bills for all Ghanaians for the next three months, i.e. April, May and June.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200430230001/http://www.presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1555-address-to-the-nation-by-president-akufo-addo-on-updates-to-ghana-s-enhanced-response-to-the-coronavirus-pandemic

Government announces relief plans for electricity in addition to earlier relief plans for water supply  "As part of measures to mitigate the effects of the pandemic on the social and economic life of the country, I indicated, in my last speech, that Government will absorb water bills for all Ghanaians for the next three months, i.e. April, May and June. Furthermore, water tankers, publicly and privately-owned, are being mobilised to ensure the supply of water to vulnerable communities. We have decided on further measures of mitigation for all Ghanaians for the next three months, i.e. April, May and June. Government will fully absorb electricity bills for the poorest of the poor, i.e. for all lifeline consumers, that is free electricity for persons who consume zero (0) to fifty (50) kilowatt hours a month for this period. In addition, for all other consumers, residential and commercial, Government will absorb, again, fifty percent (50%) of your electricity bill for this period, using your March 2020 bill as your benchmark" - Ghanaian President    https://web.archive.org/web/20200430230741/http://www.presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1560-president-akufo-addo-speaks-on-updates-to-ghana-s-enhanced-response-to-covid-19
partial lockdown for Accra and Kumasi  https://archive.vn/sW0wL
https://archive.vn/sW0wL
With the lifting of the partial lockdown of Accra and two other cities on April 19th, there does not appear to be any limits to internal movement  https://archive.vn/sW0wL

Total lockdown imposed in some key cities was lifted on April 20th in a speech by the president which states "Businesses and other workplaces can continue to operate, observing staff management and workplace protocols with the view to achieving social distancing and hygiene protocols." - No Explicit reference to working from home but it is here assumed through "social distancing and hygiene protocols" - https://web.archive.org/web/20200425193750/https://www.cnbcafrica.com/news/2020/04/20/ghana-lifts-lockdown-on-key-regions-as-covid-19-cases-reach-1042/

Operators of public transport, including our buses, trotros and taxis, are to continue to run with a minimum number of passengers.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200425193750/https://www.cnbcafrica.com/news/2020/04/20/ghana-lifts-lockdown-on-key-regions-as-covid-19-cases-reach-1042/
The President of Ghana for the first time in his speech to the country recommended the public to wear a mask whenever not at home.    https://archive.vn/CxnwV

Market places, work places, public transport, and constitutional and statutory bodies such as the Electoral Commission, the National Commission for Civic Education and the National Identification Authority, whose activities were exempted from the outset from these restrictions, must conduct their activities in accordance with social distancing and the necessary hygiene and safety protocols.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200604215546/http://www.presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1597-update-no-10-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus

Face coving became compulsory in churches and mosques.  'Each student, teacher, and non-teaching staff will be provided with re-usable face masks by the Ministry of Education.'    https://archive.vn/W5SGr

The President of Ghana said in his speech on 14 June that, 'the wearing of masks is now mandatory. Leaving our homes without a face mask or face covering on is an offence. The Police have been instructed to enforce this directive, which is the subject of an Executive Instrument.'    https://archive.vn/4PIDh

From today final year senior high school students (SHS 3), and second year Gold Track students returned to school - this was announced yesterday by the President:    https://web.archive.org/web/20200625192353/http://www.presidency.gov.gh/index.php/briefing-room/speeches/1601-update-no-12-measures-taken-to-combat-spread-of-coronavirus
Policy ended in June

'Ghana is reopening its main airport to international flight passengers from Sept. 1 ... Any passenger arriving in Ghana will have to present a negative Covid-19 result, taken no more than 72 hours before departure from the country of origin, President Nana Akufo-Addo said in a broadcast Sunday. Upon arrival, passengers will again be tested at the airport, with results to be provided within 30 minutes. International travel by land and sea are still prohibited.'  https://archive.vn/mFF9B    The President's speech on 30 August: https://archive.vn/sJY1N    Meanwhile, 'borders, by land and sea, will remain closed to human traffic until further notice'.  https://archive.vn/JrOSE

" it has been decided that the Ghana Premier League and the Division One Football League will restart on Friday, 30th October, with a full regime of testing of the players, technical and management staff. No spectators will be allowed at the training centres, and, when actual competition resumes, seating at all stadia will be limited to twenty-five percent (25%) capacity to ensure social distancing. Wearing of masks by spectators at stadia will be mandatory. The restart of all other sporting competitions will be determined on a case-by-case basis, pending consultations between the Ministry of Youth and Sports and the respective sport associations"  17th Address by President, https://archive.vn/JrOSE  While other public events may still be required to close, I understand this as "recommended" since not ALL are required to close given this exception

The government of Guinea's first reported activity on COVID-19 was an emergency meeting on 27th January 2020. This was first posted on Guinea's Ministry of Health's Facebook page and "Shared" on 28th January 2020 on the general Guinea government's Facebook page.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://mobile.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=2722865234493848&id=685140344933024&_rdc=1&_rdr

The Minister of Health makes a press release urging Guineans to take precautions to protect themselves from COVID-19. He also informs the public about the actions being taken by the government regarding the issue.     https://web.archive.org/save/https://sante.gov.gn/communique-du-gouvernement-sur-lepidemie-de-coronavirus-declaree-par-la-chine/    https://web.archive.org/save/https://mobile.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=2725823084198063&id=685140344933024&_rdc=1&_rdr

The Health Minister advises those who have symptoms of COVID-19 to go to the health centres.    "Drive to a health facility anyone showing suspicious symptoms from the affected countries. Health facilities are invited to make all arrangements for the detection and treatment of any eventual cases."    https://web.archive.org/save/https://sante.gov.gn/communique-du-gouvernement-sur-lepidemie-de-coronavirus-declaree-par-la-chine/

All international passengers are screened before being allowed into the country or quarantined: https://web.archive.org/web/20200526032847/https://mobile.facebook.com/story.php?story_fbid=2810631219050582&id=685140344933024&_rdc=1&_rdr

Reliefweb reports that the contact tracing and follow-up rate for the country is 88%.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200526064215/https://reliefweb.int/report/guinea/guinea-coronavirus-covid-19-situation-report-no-4-31-march-7-april-2020

Hygiene-related measures e.g. handwashing should be taken when congregating in groups, large group gathering should be avoided, physical contact should be avoided.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200526044458/https://twitter.com/alphacondepresi/status/1240747558970036225?

Commercial flights to and from, and visa issuance at countries with more than 30 cases of COVID-19 suspended for 30 days from March 21, 2020 at 11.59 pm, except for cargo and humanitarian flights.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200526044458/https://twitter.com/alphacondepresi/status/1240747558970036225?

Schools at all levels closed for an initial 14 days and the closures are renewable, if necessary.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200526052116/https://www.facebook.com/GouvGn/posts/1383870008486776?__tn__=K-R&_rdc=1&_rdr

All bars, games, show, cinema and other gathering places will be closed for fourteen (14) days, renewable    https://web.archive.org/web/20200526052116/https://www.facebook.com/GouvGn/posts/1383870008486776?__tn__=K-R&_rdc=1&_rdr
Religious ceremonies, houses of worship, sports events cancelled.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200526052116/https://www.facebook.com/GouvGn/posts/1383870008486776?__tn__=K-R&_rdc=1&_rdr

All meetings - including conferences - are limited to 20 people and must be carried out according the rules on physical distancing. All international conferences scheduled in Guinea are suspended or delayed until further notice.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200526052116/https://www.facebook.com/GouvGn/posts/1383870008486776?__tn__=K-R&_rdc=1&_rdr

Public transport was not closed. However, public transport of Conakry city will be subject to a passenger limit: 3 passengers per car, 1 per motorcycle, and 7 to 10 per minibus.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200526052116/https://www.facebook.com/GouvGn/posts/1383870008486776?__tn__=K-R&_rdc=1&_rdr

"On March 27, 2020, President Alpha Condé announced a state of emergency and a series of measures to curb the spread of Covid-19, including closing borders, banning large gatherings, shutting down schools, and restricting movement out of Conakry, the capital. "    https://web.archive.org/web/20200526194803/https://www.hrw.org/news/2020/04/29/guinea-respecting-rights-key-amid-covid-19-0

All land borders are closed (entry/exit) for all travellers outside the transport of goods for a period of thirty (30) renewable days.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200526052116/https://www.facebook.com/GouvGn/posts/1383870008486776?__tn__=K-R&_rdc=1&_rdr
Nationwide curfew introduced 21:00-05:00  https://web.archive.org/web/20200528182431/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/327766/guinea-authorities-announce-state-of-emergency-march-27-update-2

"In addition, a COVID-19 economic response plan was announced on April 6, 2020. The Plan aims at strengthening infrastructure in the health sector, protecting the most vulnerable, and supporting the private sector, notably small and medium enterprises. The authorities estimate the cost of the Plan at about US$ 328 million (2.3 percent of GDP). Key measures include: the introduction of temporary exonerations on taxes, social contributions and payment of utilities for firms in the most affected sectors; the implementation of labor-intensive public works, provision of cash transfers, a waiver on the payment of utilities for the most vulnerable."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201014021405/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    The plan: https://web.archive.org/web/20201014021549/http://gouvernement.gov.gn/images/ActionsGouv2020/Plan%20de%20riposte%20%C3%A9conomique%20GN_exe.pdf

https://archive.vn/Umjtw  https://archive.vn/T67lm    A compulsory face mask order kicked into effect in Guinea over the weekend (April 18) as part of government’s efforts to stem the spread of the new coronavirus.    Everyone must wear a mask and those not wearing masks will be fined 30,000 GNF.

On June 15, the state of emergency in Guinea was relaxed as the country entered 'Phase 1' of its lockdown easing plan. In this phase, remote work is recommended wherever possible, but most sectors of the economy are allowed to reopen. Decree No. 45/2020 (June 15) states that 'all economic activities of all businesses, retail, self-employed and wholesale businesses are resumed' with the conditions that masks are worn, crowds are controlled by limiting access, and social distancing is maintained.     https://archive.vn/2tEEZ
Curfew still in place; not eased until July 15    https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/360596/guinea-authorities-ease-covid-19-restrictions-on-july-15-update-9 [link not archivable]

Demonstrations are cancelled, but other events that favour the presidency aren't (see C4)

I could not find any evidence of a number of people, but given the fact that I saw plenty of pictures on the govt facebook pages of events with more than 100 attendees, and given that the President does not want big groups gathering to demonstrate before the 18 oct elections, I would place that number between 100 and 1000 people:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201014020158/https://www.dw.com/fr/guin%C3%A9e-d%C3%A9but-de-la-campagne-et-interdiction-de-manifester/a-54982250

There is a limit of 100 people assembling for marriage, baptism and funeral services in Conakry. See: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/guinea/coronavirus [web archive unavailable, accessed 22nd October 2020]

It seems like this should be coded as 0. There are currently no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel in Guinea. See: https://gn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ [web archive unavailable, accessed 22nd October 2020, web page last updates 19 October 2020]

This seems like it should be coded as 2. Negative COVID-19 tests are required, and people from countries like the US with a high number of cases, are allowed to enter into Guinea. In terms of quarantine, only those arriving travellers with outdated test results, with symptoms, or who test positive for COVID-19 on entry will be sent to a designated treatment centre under quarantine until two negative tests are completed. See: https://gn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ [web archive unavailable, accessed 22nd October 2020, web page last updates 19 October 2020]. Moreover, although Guinea's land borders are closed,  Conakry airport is open and commercial flights are gradually resuming. See: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/guinea/coronavirus [web archive unavailable, accessed 22nd October 2020]
Policy has not changed

"As planned by the Ministry of National Education,  students are on vacation from October 16 to November  15, 2020, therefore schools are closed.   The opening of the 2020-2021 school year is scheduled  for November 16, 2020 but it remains dependent on the  government's decision according to the evolution of  COVID-19.  "  https://web.archive.org/web/20201201013042/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Guinea%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20No.%2017%20-%208%20October%20-%204%20November%202020.pdf    There is a campaign to have students return to school on Dec 1.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201201012823/https://www.facebook.com/UNICEFGUINEE/posts/3784281048270158

There is a limit of 100 people assembling for marriage, baptism and funeral services in Conakry. Schools and mosques have reopened  https://web.archive.org/web/20201201011605/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/guinea/coronavirus

Movement around the country is restricted and a negative COVID test certificate within 14 days of travel outside of Conakry is required.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201201011605/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/guinea/coronavirus

All arriving and departing travelers must present the results of a negative polymerase chain reaction (PCR) COVID-19 test.  Arriving passengers:  testing must be completed no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Guinea or the traveler will be tested upon arrival and be required to quarantine for 14 days.  Arriving passengers with proof of a negative test within the 72 hours prior to arrival will not undergo any additional testing or quarantine in Guinea.  Arriving passengers with symptoms or who test positive for COVID-19 will be sent to a designated treatment center until two negative tests are completed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201201005332/https://gn.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

The daily situation report includes the numbers of contacts identified and the number of contacts that were followed up with. It appears fairly comprehensive. On Nov 29th, for example, 712 contacts were identified and 703 were followed up with.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201201014746/https://anss-guinee.org/assets/document/DOC_160672245812047426425fc4a39ac1707.pdf

Students have been on break since mid-October. UNICEF is running a Back to School Campaign for December 1.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201207231050/https://reliefweb.int/report/guinea/unicef-guinea-covid-19-situation-report-no-18-5-november-2-december-2020    The Minister of Education made a speech in support of this campaign where he described the restrictions - they seem minimal. Are contacts of the confirmed COVID19 case being traced?  Yes. The Ministry of Health has teams in place to ensure urgent contact tracing. Those identified as close contacts are now being quarantined, and will be tested, in line with the decision to test all persons in quarantine before they are released.  https://www.mrc.gm/coronavirus-covid-19-information/

In his second Nationa address to the Nation on Covid-19, the President announced that the “government has taken the decision to scale down government operations. Accordingly, all Heads of government institutions, parastatals, private enterprises and other institutions have been instructed to scale down their activities, with minimal staff to perform basic services. Where feasible, staff can work from home.”  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200423040114/https://www.freedomnewspaper.com/2020/03/27/barrow-declares-a-state-of-emergency-amid-corona-infection-cases-in-the-gambia/

on 27 March, the President announced a state of emergency and "the suspension of all public gatherings including religious convergence. Muslims in the country have for the first time desist from the weekly Friday prayers in observance of the ban on public gatherings." "All public transport shall carry half of the total number of passengers they are allowed to transport by law."   https://web.archive.org/web/20200413113849/https://www.freedomnewspaper.com/2020/03/27/barrow-declares-a-state-of-emergency-amid-corona-infection-cases-in-the-gambia/

"All public gatherings including funerals are limited to a maximum of 10 people"   https://web.archive.org/web/20200525034241/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Although people are still recommended to stay home, all markets are now open, so long as all patrons wash or sanitize hands before entering the market, and social distancing measures are maintained.    "Although the State of Emergency is currently still in effect, the government announced an easing of restrictions on June 4 reopening markets, mosques (as of June 5), and churches (as of June 7). Other restrictions – including school closures, border closures, and social gathering limitations – remain in place.  The full declaration is available on the State House of The Gambia’s Facebook and Twitter"    https://web.archive.org/web/20200608124149/https://gm.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

The government claims to be carrying out comprehensive contact tracing, and maps out all transmission and the source of each case in weekly infographics posted on its official twitter page. It's unclear to what extent these 'situational report' graphics represent the completeness of the governments contact tracing efforts, and this doesn't represent a discrete policy change, but there is now _ostensibly_ comprehensive contact tracing being carried out in the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200615182016/https://twitter.com/Presidency_GMB/status/1272594265550524422/

On July 22, the President lifted the state of Emergency that had been in effect for five months, given the negative economic impact this has had. As a result, all emergency measures are lifted, with the exception of border closures. The government continues to monitor the spread of the disease and urges the public to adhere to health measures, maintain social distancing rules, and wear masks. On 6 August Due to a surge of over 60% in the last seven days, the Gambia government imposed a 21-day state of emergency and nighttime curfew (10pm-5am), in force from 6 August to 26 August. "The government also closed down all places of worship and schools. Only a select number of establishments are allowed to continue operating. These are: grocery stores, markets, banks and all businesses classified as essential." The government attributed this surge to "citizens lowering their guard with respect to protective health measures". However, although two media reported this new measure on 6 August, there is no such announcement on the government website... http://archive.vn/XlV9N http://archive.vn/7a571

On 14 August "All educational institutions (Universities, Colleges, Schools, Madrassas, Daras, Majalis and Gamos) shall remain closed. However, Grade 12 students are exempted only for the period of their WAEC/WASSCE exams from 17th August to the 7thSeptember 2020. These schools shall open solely for the purpose of administering exit exams" Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200823134009/https://www.pmnewsnigeria.com/2020/08/06/gambia-announces-state-of-emergency-curfew-over-covid-19/

"All non-food outlets in all markets throughout The Gambia shall remain closed. Exemptions are granted to banks and financial institutions, pharmacies, drug stores, supermarkets and mini markets, local corner shops and essential food traders. The markets shall be opened between 6am and 2pm daily;"  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200823134009/https://www.pmnewsnigeria.com/2020/08/06/gambia-announces-state-of-emergency-curfew-over-covid-19/
From the March 18 order: "All public transport shall carry half of the total number of passengers they are allowed to transport by law."

"In the wake of the worrisome trajectory of the COVID-19 pandemic in The Gambia, His Excellency President Adama Barrow in exercise of the powers vested in him by Section 34 (1) (a) and pursuant to Section 34 (2) of the 1997 Constitution declares a State of Public Emergency effective midnight tonight and a curfew effective tomorrow, 6th August 2020 throughout The Gambia for a period of 21 days."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200823134009/https://www.pmnewsnigeria.com/2020/08/06/gambia-announces-state-of-emergency-curfew-over-covid-19/

"All non-food outlets in all markets throughout The Gambia shall remain closed. On October 9, the government commenced implementing the NAFA Quick Cash Transfer second phase aimed at mitigating the impact of the coronavirus pandemic. A total of USD 10 million initiated by the Gambia government and supported by the World Bank is being disbursed amongst approximately 83,000 households across the country. In the second phase, each household is receiving another three thousand dalasis (3,000 GMD). The second phase of the cash transfer nationwide is planned to be completed by middle November. The money is meant for the entire household - to buy food and other household needs.  Link: https://archive.vn/7G8Mw https://archive.vn/0mKez
President Adama Barrow has subsequently lifted the nightly curfew.   Link: https://archive.vn/bHdKx

2G – 14th Oct On October 6, the Hon. Minister of Basic and Secondary Education Claudiana Cole announced the reopening of schools throughout the country. “Schools will reopen from 14th October 2020 for grades seven to twelve and for ECD to Grade six, they shall reopen on October 28th, 2020," she stated. Minister Cole urged parents to sew face masks for their children using the same uniform material as face masks will be compulsory in schools. On October 9, the Ministry of Higher Education Research, Science, and Technology (MoHERST) announced that all TVET and tertiary institutions in the Gambia will reopen from October 14. The MoHERST noted that the reopening of these institutions should be done by adhering to the COVID-19 guidelines to reduce the risk of contracting the virus. Links: https://archive.vn/otlaW https://archive.vn/NWqjz https://archive.vn/MHKy3

The Gambia reopened its borders on October 16 after a six-month lockdown in light of the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the Gambia's international airport in the capital Banjul will not be fully operational until October 31 because of ongoing reconstruction. Foreign travelers will still be required to show evidence of negative PCR test results conducted not more than 72 hours prior to their arrival. Those with positive test results will be quarantined.  Link: https://archive.vn/1abnh  Link: https://archive.vn/Zj3t3

The re-opening of kindergartens and primary schools (which were the last levels yet to resume) began on October 28. See https://web.archive.org/web/20201109002858/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

Greece bans gatherings of more than 10 people and will impose administrative fines to each person above the cap, head of Civil protection Nikos Hardalias announced on Wednesday afternoon. Government spokesman Stelios Petsas clarified that the ban refers to gatherings not only outside but also inside. “there cannot be that there is such a ban and 10-15 people gather in a home,” he said stressing that “it is the crowding that has to be avoided to contain the virus spread.”    /web/20200426121631/https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/04/greece-flattened-coronavirus-curve-200407191043404.html     /web/20200426122214/https://www.keeptalkinggreece.com/2020/03/18/coronavirus-greece-ban-gatherings-of-more-than-10-people-fines-restrictions/

Shipping Minister Giannis Plakiotakis announced on Friday that only permanent residents and supply trucks will be allowed to travel to the Aegean islands, in a bid to ban the unnecessary movement of people within the country and halt the spread of the new coronavirus.  The ban will come into force from 6 a.m. this Saturday  https://web.archive.org/web/20200504094657/https://www.ekathimerini.com/250865/article/ekathimerini/news/government-bans-travel-to-the-islands-for-non-residents

the Greek government announced a ban on all nonessential transport and movement across the country, starting from 6 a.m on 23 March until 6 April. Movement is permitted only for a prescribed set of reasons that include moving to or from the workplace during normal business hours, shopping for food or medicine, visiting a doctor or assisting a person in need of help, exercising individually or in pairs or walking a pet, attending a ceremony (wedding, baptism, funeral etc.), Journeys by car are only permitted for the specific exemptions, and the driver may only have one passenger in the vehicle  /web/20200426120742/https://www.in.gr/2020/03/22/greece/apagoreysi-kykloforias-analytikos-odigos-pou-tha-epitrepetai-metakinisi-ti-tha-isxysei-gia-tous-ergazomenous/  /web/20200426121254/https://greekcitytimes.com/2020/03/23/the-greek-lockdown-explained-the-dos-and-donts/

Greece will impose a total ban on public movement as of 6 a.m. Monday to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis said Sunday in a televised address. Movement is permitted only for a prescribed set of reasons that include moving to or from the workplace during normal business hours, shopping for food or medicine, visiting a doctor or assisting a person in need of help, exercising individually or in pairs or walking a pet, attending a ceremony (wedding, baptism, funeral etc.), Journeys by car are only permitted for the specific exemptions, and the driver may only have one passenger in the vehicle  /web/20200426120742/https://www.in.gr/2020/03/22/greece/apagoreysi-kykloforias-analytikos-odigos-pou-tha-epitrepetai-metakinisi-ti-tha-isxysei-gia-tous-ergazomenous/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200504094904/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/europe/greece-to-go-on-total-lockdown-prime-minister/1775375

Greek health authorities are urging the country’s residents to wear a mask at all times particularly in public spaces where contact with others is inevitable in efforts to keep the spread of Covid-19 in check.    As the government prepares to start easing restrictions on movement next week, Health Ministry spokesman Sotiris Tsiodras underlined the importance of wearing face masks in closed public areas to avert the spread of the coronavirus and said health authorities are working on an infomercial with instructions on how to make them. The use of masks on public transport is particularly important, Tsiodras said, noting that the use of surgical masks is not necessary and home-made masks, made of either paper or fabric, are also effective, in line with European Center for Disease Prevention and Control guidelines.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201018160429/https://greekcitytimes.com/2020/04/28/citizens-required-to-wear-masks-in-public-sotiris-tsiodras/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200609172454/https://news.gtp.gr/2020/04/29/greece-sets-face-mask-rule-contain-covid-19-spread/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200609071246/https://www.ekathimerini.com/252245/article/ekathimerini/news/advice-on-use-of-face-masks-against-covid-19

The restriction is valid for the period from 4.5.2020 to 18.5.2020. The Government and the Ministry of Education and Religions, taking into account the unanimous proposal of the committee of experts, decided to gradually reopen the educational structures, taking all the necessary measures to protect public health.    The reopening of educational structures is as follows:    On Monday, May 11, the courses of the 3rd Lyceum will start again, while from Monday, May 18, 2020, the rest of the classes of the Lyceum and all the classes of the High School will follow.    Tuition centers and language centers follow the gradual reopening of the respective educational level  https://web.archive.org/save/https://covid19.gov.gr/menoume-asfalis-stadiaki-epanalitourgia-ton-ekpedeftikon-domon/

A mask or facial cover is mandatory in public transportation, taxis, elevators, hospitals, clinics and diagnostic centres.  Masks are recommended in supermarkets, hair salons and other enclosed spaces - suggests that people are recommended to stay at home, but if they go out, they need to observe these guidelines. See: https://web.archive.org/save/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Travel by ferry to and from islands is permitted.  Masks are required.  Passengers must complete a health status questionnaire and submit to a temperature check prior to boarding for trips longer than 30 minutes. See: https://web.archive.org/save/https://gr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The first COVID-19 case was diagnosed in Greece on February 26th. Contact tracing was initiated on the first and all subsequent confirmed cases, with all contacts being tested and isolated. See: https://web.archive.org/save/https://eody.gov.gr/en/current-state-of-covid-19-outbreak-in-greece-and-timeline-of-key-containment-events/

It was decided by the Government to reopen the kindergartens, primary and special education schools of all levels from Monday, June 1, 2020.    This decision was based on the following factors:    First and foremost, in the unanimous proposal of the Public Health Emergency Management Committee by Infectious Diseases for the reopening of these school structures. This suggestion is certainly linked to the steadily declining course of the epidemic, with children having a harder time transmitting and transmitting the virus, and now that the temperature is rising, the safest time to open schools is epidemiologically. Since the beginning of this health crisis, we have had the privilege of being guided by an excellent team of experts, whose recommendations we follow with very good, internationally recognized results. So we go now, and we thank them warmly.  The overall de-escalation of measures has been very positive. As for schools, the previous experience of opening high schools and lyceums is very encouraging. The protection and prevention measures are modeled on the members of the educational community and everything has gone extremely smoothly.  We must ensure the return of all students to their physical space, which is none other than school. The long absence from school hinders their learning process, their spiritual, social, mental development. Primary school students are already out of school for almost 3 months, and would have been there for a total of 6 months if the schools had not been opened now. There can be no regularity without open schools.  Children are safer in school, where they follow rules and follow protection and prevention measures, rather than in neighborhoods and squares without rules. There is no better place than school to adapt and get children used to the new reality. To learn to pay more attention to every aspect of their daily lives.  Open schools reduce social inequalities and empower children from more vulnerable family backgrounds. Students who do not have modern technological equipment, students who experience tension in their family environment, students of the smallest mainly classes who do not have family guidance for distance education.  Regarding special schools, students attending these schools have a special need to be back in their school environment, with their teachers and classmates. And they obviously need it for their learning development but also for their psycho-emotional and social development.  I now turn to how these educational structures reopen:    Regarding primary and secondary schools, they will reopen on Monday, June 1. Classes will be extended until Friday, June 26 (instead of June 15), while for teachers as a whole, the end of the school year will be June 30. For substitute teachers, their contracts will be extended until June 30.  School and kindergarten departments will operate with up to 15 students at a time and with a distance of 1.5 meters on the desks, which will have the same orientation. If the students exceed 15, then the department will be divided into 2 sub-departments, and will operate in rotation, Monday-Wednesday-Friday one, Tuesday-Thursday the other, and next week the opposite. If the students do not exceed 15, then the class will be open daily.  There will be antiseptics in the rooms, cleaning is provided twice a day, both during and after school. Special legislation and additional funds have been provided for the amendment of the contracts of the cleaning staff, as well as the possibility for the recruitment of additional cleaning staff. We thank the Ministry of Interior and the Municipalities for the excellent cooperation in this area.  Breaks are provided at different times to reduce congestion, and canteens are not allowed to operate.  Natural ventilation of the rooms is provided, the use of the mask is optional for teachers and students (both at school and on school buses), special EODY instructions will be sent in the coming days to all primary education structures, and a significant part of the first day will be dedicated to explanation of these instructions. There is a special concern for teachers who fall into the category of special leave of absence as defined by the Ministry of Interior. There is also the possibility of a student being absent, on the basis of a simple responsible statement from a parent or guardian about the existence of a person in the home who belongs to an increased risk group or who is ill.  There is the possibility of modern distance learning by teachers for those students who fall into categories that justify their absence.  For the time being, all-day schools will not be open.  For special schools: they will reopen on June 1st to June 12th for secondary school and until June 26th for primary school. The competent subcommittee of infectious diseases specialists is meeting today to give special instructions for the reopening of the special education units. There will be strict protection measures    https://web.archive.org/web/20200618002455/https://www.minedu.gov.gr/news/45093-25-05-20-omilia-tis-ypourgoy-paideias-thriskevmaton-nikis-kerameos-gia-ta-dimotika-sxoleia-kai-nipiagogeia-2

From 1/6/2020, the shift work in the Public Services ceases. The personal presence of employees rising to 100% (except for those employees who are absent with special purpose leave) implies the need for strict observance of the rules of health protection such as:    - the distance between the workers at least 1.5 meters,    - taking all necessary measures to ensure the rules of hygiene by the competent personnel departments, as well as    - the observance of individual hygiene and safety measures within the framework of individual responsibility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200618003338/https://covid19.gov.gr/pafsi-tis-ek-peritropis-ergasias-stis-dimosies-ypiresies-2/

In addition to prior support through the indemnity and focused income support, from 1 June until at least 30 September, the Greek government provides 60% income support through the COOPERATION program funded by European SURE initiative in the formal sector.  "The state undertakes the obligation of replacement by 60% of the employee's income for the time that the employee will not work. In addition, in the event that the net remuneration after the above adjustment falls short of the minimum wage, the difference will be fully covered by the state."  http://archive.fo/9J9Qv

Museums reopen on June 15, 2020 , complying with all necessary protection measures. Special safe use protocols are applied, adapted to the specifics of each Museum, which define not only the maximum number of visitors, but also the safe routes of browsing and viewing, entrance and exit.  http://archive.fo/iF4ul

The list of countries that have been "opening the borders" for tourists since June 15, with flights to Athens and Thessaloniki, is announced .    The list of 29 countries was formed after a study of the epidemiological profile of the countries of origin of tourists and after taking into account yesterday's announcements of the European Air Safety Agency (EASA), as well as the relevant recommendation of the Infectious Diseases Committee.    Visitors from the following countries will be sampled.    The existing rules still apply to all other countries.    The list, which will be expanded starting on July 1, will be announced in time. In any case, epidemiological monitoring and evaluation will be ongoing.     In detail, the list of countries is as follows:     Albania, Australia, Austria, Northern Macedonia, Bulgaria, Germany, Denmark, Switzerland, Estonia, Japan, Israel, China, Croatia, Cyprus, Latvia, Lebanon, Lithuania, Malta, Montenegro, Romania, New Zealand, Norway , Serbia, Slovakia, Slovenia, Czech Republic, Finland.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200618005955/https://covid19.gov.gr/i-lista-me-tis-chores-pou-apo-tis-15-iouniou-anigoun-ta-synora-gia-tous-touristes-me-aeroporikes-ptisis-pros-athina-ke-thessaloniki/

Greenland introduced a range of measures on 18 March, but these did not include a requirement to stay at home. They do encourage people to stay at home, particularly if they have recently returned from overseas or have symptoms.  See: http://web.archive.org/web/20200426151148/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/190320-Nye-tiltag-mod-spredning-af-COVID_19-i-Nuuk

No citizens can leave the capital centre of Nuuk, which is where Greenland's recorded cases are. Travel is also strongly advised against in other regions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200426151148/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/190320-Nye-tiltag-mod-spredning-af-COVID_19-i-Nuuk

Schools are closed nationwide: "All educational institutions and private as well as public day care institutions in Nuuk will be closed. Emergency care is provided."   https://web.archive.org/web/20200803153234/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/1803_tiltag_begraensninger

"Package to support employees in private companies:  107 DKK million has been set aside to compensate for wage costs for the employees in Greenland that private companies choose to send home instead of dismissing as a result of the COVID-19 situation."    Later announcements confirm that the wage costs provided by the government to private companies are 75% of wages, but are later increased to 90%.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200803170318/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/2103_Hjaelpepakker    https://web.archive.org/web/20200803171134/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/04/2304_Loenkompensation
Complete contact tracing done for confirmed cases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200803163259/https://arctic-council.org/en/news/coronavirus-in-the-arctic-it-is-imperative-to-keep-the-virus-out/

Translated from Danish:   'On Thursday, the first SMS will be sent from the three authorities who jointly control the efforts to prevent the spread of infection - namely the Naalakkersuisut, the National Medical Association and the Greenland Police.    The SMS will encourage you to follow our advice - keep your distance and wash your hands frequently - because it slows down the spread of infection.'    https://web.archive.org/web/20200506123325/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/03/2603_sms

On April 14, the education will gradually start for primary schools outside Nuuk and in all the educational institutions of the country under special instructions (with guidelines). It is a political decision that schools and daycare centers in Nuuk continue to be closed until further notice.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200513103940/https://en.unesco.org/covid19/educationresponse  https://web.archive.org/web/20200506133938/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/04/0704_nye_retningslinier

Daycare centres and primary schools in Nuuk to open from Monday 20th, due to the success of opening outside of Nuuk.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200629103101/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/04/1704_institutioner

The departure ban from the capital centre Nuuk was lifted at the end of the day 21 April. It remains the government's recommendation that people limit internal travel.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200426152137/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/04/2104_udrejseforbud

Naalakkersuisoq Karl Frederik Danielsen announced that from 25 April at 8 am, 'Recommendation for meetings of a maximum of 100 persons'    https://web.archive.org/web/20200506142525/https://www.nun.gl/Nyheder_COVID19/2020/04/2204_Groenland_aabner_op_i_to_faser?sc_lang=da
Workplaces open from April 27th.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200629102515/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/04/2204_genaabning
As Greenland begins to ease restrictions, public transit resumes. International travel still restricted.   http://archive.vn/wip/jOZwP

Testing strategy is widened to make testing compulsory for all entrants to Greenland:  "The test strategy is as follows:  - All entrants from Denmark to Greenland are tested for COVID-19 before departure, followed by a 14-day quarantine on arrival at the destination.  - On the 5th day upon arrival, all travelers to cities must be tested for coronavirus at the local health center or regional hospital.  If the destination is a settlement, only the quarantine rules apply. If you have the opportunity to be quarantined for 5 days in the nearest town before leaving for your village, the test can take place there. Testing in settlements fraset in Kangerlussuaq cannot be performed.  All entrants and citizens with symptoms, and who have had or have contact with entrants, will be able to be tested.  Selected patient groups who do not belong to a risk group for infection, but who have symptoms of COVID-19 infection, will to a limited extent also be offered testing. This is carried out as part of the monitoring of Covid-19 in Greenland."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200803163020/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/05/0305_teststrategi

Office of Medical Officer of Health maintains that schools are open across the country with safety measures in place (since an executive order was issued on 29 May) - website updated 11 June)  "Teaching is normal for primary schools throughout the country and in all the country's educational institutions under special instruction that takes into account:  as much space as possible around the pupils / students; Among other things, by utilizing all the school institution's areas, maximum utilization of the school day, etc.  that all advice on hygiene is observed as far as possible: physical distance, hand hygiene, hand alcohol.  that canteen - restaurant meets the requirements of shops"  http://archive.fo/tkZEq

With Greenland opening, only those home-quarantining are asked to remain home.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200616031705/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/06/120620-Genaabning-den-15_-juni-fastholdes

"In connection with the reopening, it is important that everyone in Greenland follows: - The health professional advice - The rules of entry - Home quarantine rules The health advice is: - Keep distance - Wash hands frequently and use handshake - Cough or sneeze in the sleeve  Travelers from Denmark must: - Be tested negative 2-5 days before departure - Filling in the Sumut form - When you come to Greenland you must go directly into the home quarantine - On the 5th day of your home quarantine, re-test for Covid-19  If your re-test is negative, your quarantine will end If your test is positive - your home insulation will begin, and your GP will contact you about your new precautions  For home quarantine: - That you should stay in your home as far as possible - You may want to go out, but avoid contact with other people - keep away  Home quarantine does not apply to the other household if you can avoid close physical contact and focus on good hygiene."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200616031730/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/da/Naalakkersuisut/Nyheder/2020/06/120620-Genaabning-den-15_-juni-fastholdes

Translated:  "It is now possible to hold public events within current municipal boundaries with certain restrictions. It is the organizer's responsibility to ensure that there is no participation from persons from other municipalities or that they are encouraged to do so.  The purpose of the adaptations is to meet the desire for permission to organize events at the same time as the desire to minimize the risk of infection spread, it is stated."    News link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200628151606/https://sermitsiaq.ag/nye-regler-private-offentlige-arrangementer  Official announcement (in Danish):  https://naalakkersuisut.gl/~/media/Nanoq/Files/Kundgoerelser/DK/2020/Bekendtgoerelser/Selvstyrets%20bekendtgrelse%20nr%2021%20af%2019%20juni%202020%20da.pdf

Updated guidance on testing maintains existing guidelines on testing policy:  "Guidelines for corona tests in Greenland  For citizens in Greenland  Citizens with symptoms who have had or have contact with entrants will be able to be tested  Selected patient groups who do not belong to a risk group for infection, but who have symptoms of COVID-19 infection, will to a limited extent also be offered testing. This is carried out as part of the monitoring of COVID-19 in Greenland"  http://archive.fo/mncES    Coding as 2, as the clause for 1 (both symptomatic and contact with entrants) as well as 2 (testing for symptomatic groups, albeit limited to some extent) are being met

The government's 'Entry to Greenland' page archived on August 10th was "updated on the 21st of July", which is the date the "Self-Government Executive Order no. 26 of 20 July 2020 on conditions for entry to Greenland (Phase 2)" came into effect.   The code has changed from 1G to 0 on July 21st because there are no further restrictions, required or recommended, on internal movement, for those who aren't recent entrants to Greenland.  However, the Executive Order describes required quarantine upon arrival into Greenland and related restrictions on internal movement "before it is considered proven that they [entrants to Greenland] are not infected with Covid-19". This movement restriction is specifically an international travel policy and therefore accounted for under international travel restrictions. C8-2 shows there is a quarantine policy in place.  "Your trip depends on your final destination   If you have passed a negative COVID-19 test before departure and filled in the SUMUT form, you can travel to the following cities without further restrictions.   The 10 towns and two villages are:   Municipality of Sermersooq   - Nuuk   - Paamiut   Qeqqata Municipality   - Sisimiut   - Maniitsoq   - Kangerlussuaq   Municipality Kujalleq   - Qaqortoq   - Narsaq   - Narsarsuaq   Municipality Qeqertalik   - Aasiaat   - Qasigiannguit   - Qeqertarsuaq   Avannaata Municipality   - Ilulissat   If your final destination is not figuerer above list you   Stay in the city with health center that is closest to your final destination.   If you have a home address in Greenland, you can contact the authorities regarding accommodation facilities for test results.   If you do not have an address in your final destination, you must maintain the expenses that may be associated with overnight stays, rebookings, board and lodging.   Contact your local health center and order a COVID-19 test to be performed at 5 p.m.   In the event of a negative test result, you can travel on to your final destination.   3. In the event of a positive result, you must go directly into isolation. The health center will contact the National Board of Health for further clarification of your situation."   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200810150502/https://nun.gl/Emner/Borgere/Coronavirus_emne/Rejser_til_Groenland_fra_den_15_juni?sc_lang=da  (Entry to Greenland page) & http://web.archive.org/web/20201110102927/https://naalakkersuisut.gl/~/media/Nanoq/Files/Kundgoerelser/DK/2020/Bekendtgoerelser/Selvstyrets%20bekendtgrelse%20nr%2026%20af%2020%20juli%202020%20om%20betingelser%20for%20indrejse%20til%20Grnland%20Fase%202%20da.pdf (Executive Order)

Since July 21, travellers were not required to self-quarantine upon arrival in Greenland or re-test for COVID-19 after arrival. See: https://dk.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19-information/ (web archive link not working)

Weekly update of Danish list of ’open and banned countries’, applies to entry into Greenland as well. Entrants from banned countries can only enter under certain conditions e.g. if they are employed or are students in the country.     Banned European countries now include : Belgium, Bulgaria, Malta, Luxembourg, Romania, Spain. Belgium, Spain, Malta are new additions since the update from the previous week on 30 July.  Countries other than EU Member States, Schengen countries and the United Kingdom are currently by definition 'banned' countries, with the following exceptions: Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, South Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, and Uruguay.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://politi.dk/en/coronavirus-in-denmark/travelling-in-or-out-of-denmark/is-my-country-open-or-banned
Denmark has only reopened its borders for international tourism, allowing in both EU nations and a few select countries outside of the EU to now visit.

Executive Order nr 37 from 29 September regarding travelling to and in Greenland is valid from 30 September 2020 through 31 January 2021.    Entrance requirements:  - Upon check-in one must show a maximum 5 day old negative Corona test.  - They must also show a confirmation of the completed Sumut form, a personal locator form, which advises where you will be visiting and whom you will come in contact with. This form can be downloaded at www.sumut2020.    Due to the high Reproduction factor in Denmark and other countries, the earlier quarantine rules are now back in effect. This means that all travellers upon arrival in Greenland must:    - go into 14 days quarantine if you are not re-tested in Greenland.  - go into quarantine until receipt of a negative re-test result, which can be first conducted on day 5 after arrival.    https://web.archive.org/save/https://visitgreenland.com/articles/corona-virus-status/

In Greenland, you are required to wear a bandage(mask) in the following situations:    1. For international and domestic flights.  This applies to everyone over the age of 12 as well as the cabin crew, with a few exceptions when on the plane, staying at airports or terminal areas.  When employed with passenger contact in terminal areas and the like, you must wear a bandage or visor if a plastic screen cannot be set up between employees and travelers. Reference is also made to § 6 and § 7 Self-Government Executive Order no. 37 of 29 September 2020 on conditions for travel to and in Greenland  2. If you are infected or at risk of being infected with a new coronavirus and exceptionally have to move out, eg because you need to be tested.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201006064205/https://nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/rejser_til_groenland_fra_den_15_juni?sc_lang=da

The Ministry of Business and Labor released “Guidelines of September 2020 establishing detailed criteria for application, award and administration of funds under the labor market package”   “Wage costs must:…B. relate to the period 19 March 2020 - 30 September 2020, both days inclusive.” No policies which have extended the period of wage costs beyond September 30th have been found.  “3. Compensation is limited to salary expenses for the following employees  A. Employees with a permanent connection to the company. Firm affiliation means that there must be an employment contract between employee and company for the company to receive salary compensation for the employee. The agreement must have been entered into before 19 March 2020.  Loose workers are not covered as they do not have a permanent affiliation with the company. Loose workers are characterized by the employment is only very short-lived so that the employment is terminated when e.g. day work is over and the employee is not committed to work the following day. The employment relationship must have one duration exceeding 2 days. The employment must be permanent”  “The compensation is calculated as follows:  A. 90% of the salary expense, however, a maximum of DKK 20,190, per 30 days wage compensation period per. employee.   B. If the wage compensation period is shorter than 30 days, is calculated compensation as a proportionate share rounded to nearest whole day.  C. Deducting any other support from public funds to the applicant concerning the same wage cost.”   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201019212330/https://www.businessingreenland.gl/~/media/Erhverv/COVID-19/30%20september/DK%20Retningslinjer%20vedr%20arbejdsmarkedspakke%20pr%2030%20september%202020.pdf?la=da

There have been no updates to Greenland’s testing guidelines for citizens, on The Office of the Medical Director of Health website, since August 20, 2020.   It remains the case:  “Citizens with symptoms who have had or have contact with entrants will be able to be tested  Selected patient groups who do not belong to a risk group for infection, but who have symptoms of COVID-19 infection, will to a limited extent also be offered testing. This is carried out as part of the monitoring of COVID-19 in Greenland.”  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201108232920/https://www.nun.gl/emner/borgere/coronavirus_emne/hvem_bliver_testet_for_covid_19?sc_lang=da

Visit Greenland’s Q&A response to ‘Who can enter Greenland’ is “Travellers with residence in the following countries have conditional permission to travel to the Kingdom of Denmark, including Greenland – see here. The numbers are re-evaluated on a weekly basis, and therefore a country’s status can change between open and closed. There is no longer a limit on how many persons may arrive to Greenland.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201108215641/https://visitgreenland.com/corona-faq/  A hyperlink followed by pressing “see here” went to a coronavirus site ran by the Danish Authorities which had a    “List of high-risk countries within the EU and the Schengen area as well as the United Kingdom applicable from 7 November 2020 00.00 (in Danish)  Countries/regions added to the list of banned countries  Innlandet, Norway?Oslo, Norway?Vestland, Norway?Viken, Norway?Västerbotten, Sweden?Västernorrland, Sweden?Estonia”   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201108215839/https://coronasmitte.dk/en/entry-into-denmark/is-my-country-open-or-banned  Also, “From Monday 9 November, the airspace over Greenland will be closed and therefore there can only be approach to Greenland from Copenhagen Airport. Certain types of flights are excluded, such as emergency flights.” “The increased control over the entrance to Greenland is taking place as an additional measure to protect Greenland in relation to the Corona infection. It is the Self-Government that has asked the Danish authorities to close the airspace in order to have gathered all travelers in one place and thus ensure that everyone is subjected to the same control and test, as well as information. It is not yet known how long the closure will last.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201108220102/https://www.nun.gl/nyheder_covid19/2020/11/0611_kun-en-indgang-til-groenland?sc_lang=da

On March 21, President Giammattei announced that, effective Sunday, March 22, a nationwide curfew will take effect. The curfew is from 4:00 p.m. to 4:00 a.m. and is scheduled to be in effect until March 29. Everyone in Guatemala, including foreigners, is expected to remain in their homes during curfew hours. The only exceptions are for police, private security, medical professionals and ambulances, food delivery drivers, and certain other essential personnel. While food delivery service will continue during the curfew, grocery stores are expected to close before the curfew takes effect.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200501170432/https://gt.usembassy.gov/guatemala-begins-curfew-starting-march-22/

"From tomorrow a curfew will go into effect in our country for eight days from four in the afternoon until four in the morning of the next day,” he said.      https://web.archive.org/web/20200506164834/https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-health-coronavirus-central-america/el-salvador-guatemala-ramp-up-coronavirus-fight-impose-curfews-idUKKBN21906B

That the IGSS will carry out the diagnostic tests to rule out suspected cases of the COVID-19 disease, these tests will be run only to those people who have symptoms or suspicion of this disease, such as dry cough, fever and difficulty breathing or any link epidemiological.
