Sources: http://www.health.gov.sc/index.php/covid-19/faqs/  http://web.archive.org/web/20201003103652/http://www.nation.sc/articles/6295/covid-19-update

No restrictions on private gatherings are noted in government sites. In addition, the US embassy specifically captures that "Restrictions on the movement of people are no longer in effect, however, social distancing measures remain in place." For this reason, it seemed best to reduce the restriction coding to mirror that of public events. https://web.archive.org/web/20201026183524/https://mu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-seychelles/

In line with revised WHO interim guideline 05.06.2020, use of mask by the general public is  recommended under the following conditions: if a person has symptoms or Specific settings where the physical distance of at least 1m cannot be maintained between persons. https://web.archive.org/web/20200919125423/http://www.health.gov.sc/wp-content/uploads/Guidance-for-the-general-public-on-the-usage-of-mask.pdf  individuals
No policy change

"The Health Ministry is implementing strict measures at border crossing points to monitor the health of arriving passengers and detect any suspected cases of Coronavirus given the rapid spread of the virus around the world.    Director of the Health Center at Damascus International Airport Dr. Khuzama Zreiq said that the center’s medical staff and ambulances are on full alert 24/7, and that the measures being taken include providing protective coats and masks, and measuring the temperatures of passengers using remote thermometers to prevent direct contact with the subjects, as elevated body temperature is one of the first signs of patients infected by the virus."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200519090135/https://sana.sy/en/?p=184053

"the Cabinet commissioned the Information and Health Ministries to formulate a comprehensive media plan for raising awareness about protection against this virus, in addition to commissioning the Education and Higher Education Ministries to enhance preventative measures at schools and universities" https://www.sana.sy/en/?p=187790

"The necessary precautions to ensure Syrians are protected from the arrival of the coronavirus were on the discussion table for government ministers at the cabinet session headed by Imad Khamis on Sunday.    The cabinet stressed the need to monitor the precautionary and preventive measures taken at all ports, land, sea and air crossings, to ensure that no cases of coronavirus occur on Syrian territory. It decided to suspend visits and trips to and from the neighboring countries of Iraq and Jordan by individuals and groups, including for purposes of religious tourism, for one month. It also suspended visits to countries that have declared a state of epidemic for two months, while conducting preventive quarantine for a period of 14 days for those coming from these countries to ensure their safety."    Sources:   https://syrianobserver.com/EN/news/56590/the-government-takes-precautionary-measures-and-forbids-visits-to-iraq-and-jordan-for-a-month.html (unable to archive)

""The governmental team tasked with confronting the Coronavirus (COVID-19) conducted on Friday a comprehensive evaluation and review of the precautionary measures which have been taken, and it adopted a number of additional decisions to deal with the developments related to pandemic.    During its meeting on Friday, chaired by Prime Minister Imad Khams, the team called on citizens to show a high level of awareness and responsibility in terms of commitment to “voluntary isolation” procedures that should maintain public safety so that “mandatory isolation” is not enforced in the case of non-compliance."    Source: https://archive.vn/cpzd1

"Due to the expanding threat of Coronavirus around the world as it has become a global pandemic, the Syrian government took a number of precautionary and preventative steps to protect citizens.    (...)The team also decided to reduce work hours at administrative public sector establishments to around 40%, suspending handprint sign-in for a month. Economic services establishments are to reorganize work to function in the optimal manner with the minimum amount of workers for 15 days. Work in the public and private sectors will continue for technicians and production workers after providing the suitable preventative measures and providing medical staff for conducting regular checkups.    In addition, restaurants and cafes are to refrain from providing hookah (water pipe), and venues for social gatherings have been closed, while a plan has been devised to sanitize public transportation."    Source: https://archive.vn/AA0so

"The government’s measures and raising the health sector’s readiness are preventive and precautionary measures to control the spread of infection if any infection is recorded, he clarified.  (...) The precautionary steps, included suspending universities, schools, and institutes as of 14/03/2020 to 02/04/2020 (...)"  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20201111120611/https://www.sana.sy/en/?p=188258

The Cabinet of Syria formulates a set of preventative measures to help curb the spread of coronavirus across the country. The measures are not specific in what constitutes a "gathering," however it can be inferred that the measures are quite strict. "Suspension of all scientific, cultural, social and sporting events that require gathering of people, strict prevention of crowds in cafes and restaurants, closure of public services halls (used for weddings, funerals etc.) and implementing a plan to sanitize public transport.".     Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200428132151/https://www.insideover.com/society/syrian-emergency-measures-to-counter-coronavirus-pandemic.html;

The Cabinet of Syria formulates a set of preventative measures to help curb the spread of coronavirus across the country. The measures are not specific in what constitutes a "gathering," however it can be inferred that the measures are quite strict. "d- Suspension of all scientific, cultural, social and sporting events that require gathering of people, strict prevention of crowds in cafes and restaurants, closure of public services halls (used for weddings, funerals etc.) and implementing a plan to sanitize public transport.". http://web.archive.org/web/20200428132151/https://www.insideover.com/society/syrian-emergency-measures-to-counter-coronavirus-pandemic.html; https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/03/concern-mounts-catastrophic-coronavirus-outbreak-syria-200316003354976.html

Cabinet suspended all forms of mass public and private transportation within provinces as of 8 PM on Monday and between provinces as of 8 PM on Tuesday, with the stipulation that ministries, union, and private production establishments provide transportation for their workers    https://web.archive.org/web/20200324021223/https://sana.sy/en/?p=188663

"The government team tasked with following up on the procedures for confronting the Coronavirus (COVID-19) issued a decision to enforce a nighttime curfew across Syria from 6 PM to 6 AM as of Wednesday 25/03/2020, with all commercial activities and shops to be closed completely during curfew times."    Source: https://archive.vn/hpgvv

From the 25th of March, the government has ordered the suspension of transport within the following governorates: Lattakia, Aleppo, Tartus, Hama, Homs, Qunaitara, Deraa and Deir Al Zour. Althought these are 8 out of 14 governorates and if we count areas held by opposition forced in the North East and other armed groups in the North West, the move amounts to a total suspension of public transportation except in the capital Damascus.     Source (in Arabic): https://web.archive.org/web/20200406114651/https://www.sana.sy/?p=1126990

The restriction on movement between the Syrian governates which was approved by the Syrian government during its weekly session on Sunday the 29th of March is now effective (from 6 pm on the 31st of March and until the 16th of April)   Source: in Arabic: https://web.archive.org/web/20200402161144/https://www.sana.sy/?p=1130687

https://web.archive.org/web/20200518202732/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-response-update-no02-6-may-2020  OCHA  “On 16 April, the WHO Regional Office for the Eastern Mediterranean (EMRO) shared information indicating that a 53-year-old man from Al-Hasakeh City who had been admitted to Qamishli National Hospital on 27 March had died on 2 April. A test for the virus subsequently tested positive.”

"The Government of Syria (GoS) continues to implement a range of preventive measures, with some recent relaxations announced (...)  after a two-day exemption on 20 and 21 April, a ban on travel between governorates and also travel within governorates to and from urban and rural centers, with some exemptions remains in place."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201110222008/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update%20No%207_25Apr2020_FINAL.pdf

"The Government of Syria (GoS) continues to implement a range of preventive measures, with some recent relaxations announced (...)  after a two-day exemption on 20 and 21 April, a ban on travel between governorates and also travel within governorates to and from urban and rural centers, with some exemptions remains in place." In GoS-controlled areas, the daily curfew and the travel ban between and within governorates were lifted from 26 May (...) Public and private transportation services have also resumed." "Syria announced on Monday it will lift a night-time curfew, starting Tuesday (May 26) evening, and will allow movement between governorates, state television said.  The government (...) left the door open to the possibility of re-imposing a total curfew, depending on developments with the virus."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201112122136if_/https://br.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-syria-curfew/syria-lifts-night-time-curfew-from-tuesday-allows-movement-between-governorates-idUSKBN2311ZS

"Beginning today, the government will lift an overnight curfew and allow movement between its provinces."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200527094103/https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/05/syria-coronavirus-curfew-uptick-cases-damascus-idlib.html    "Restrictions remain in place at most other crossing points inside Syria. Abu Zendin, Um Jloud and Awn Dadat in Aleppo remain closed, as do Akeirshi and Abu Assi crossing points in Ar-Raqqa. Ghazawiyet Afrin and Al-Taiha in Aleppo are reported open for commercial traffic; the latter is also reported to be currently open for university students to move into GoS areas, in addition to some medical cases (...)"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201110223052/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update%20No%2011_30May2020_FINAL.pdf
No restrictions/recommendations for staying at home were found, after the end of the celebrations of Eid-al-Adha.

The Education Ministry instructed its directorates in all provinces to open the schools designated for the basic education for Category B students from Saturday till Thursday each weak from August 11th to the 31st in order to make up for educational losses through remedial lessons.  The students covered by this plan will attend the remedial classes at the nearest school to their homes with a B curriculum , with no more than 20 students in each classroom, all of whom will undergo temperature scans along with teachers and staff, noting that teachers and staff must be under 55 years of age and free of chronic diseases.  http://archive.vn/WOeL8

There is no evidence that the "For Syria stay at home" campaign is still ongoing and no campaign seems to have been announced recently. Since the curfew and movement restrictions have ended it is likely the campaign has ended.    The website, which shows the distribution of registered Coronavirus cases in Syria, is still active.    Sources: https://archive.vn/Met25  https://archive.vn/9jv5Y
End of remedial lessons.

"More than 3 million Syrian students started school in government-held areas Sunday, marking the first school day amid strict measures to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, state media reported.  Among the precautionary measures taken by the Ministry of Education were the sanitizing of all classrooms, walls, floors, stairs and bathrooms of schools, state news agency SANA said. Students’ temperatures will be checked as well." Unable to find any other information except this, posted on Nov 12th: On 30 October, a 10-day partial curfew came into effect across NES lasting until 8 November. All major markets/public facilities have been ordered closed for the duration of the ban, excluding shops selling food and restaurants (for takeaway orders only provided they close by 3pm in the afternoon); places of worship must close except for Friday prayers and Sunday mass and; mass gatherings (wedding halls, condolence tents and conference meetings all specifically mentioned) are prohibited.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201124000615/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-response-update-no-12-9-november-2020
Unable to find any information:   https://web.archive.org/web/20201124000615/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-response-update-no-12-9-november-2020

Lockdown occurred 6 November to last until 19 November. no further notations if it continued past 19 Nov. https://web.archive.org/web/20201124000615/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-response-update-no-12-9-november-2020    Under this lockdown, schools (excluding shops selling food between 6 am and 1 pm), places of worship, shops, restaurants, playgrounds and private clinics will be closed, while movements in and out of Derik city will be prohibited (excluding emergency cases and food shipments). Humanitarian actors are exempted from these restrictionsOn 3 November, following a recent surge in cases in Malakiyeh (Derik), the Executive Council of Jazeera Canton announced a full 14-day lockdown in ‘Derik city and its countryside’ (understood as the whole of Malakiyeh District) which will come into effect on 6 November and last until 19 November.    Under this lockdown, schools (excluding shops selling food between 6 am and 1 pm), places of worship, shops, restaurants, playgrounds and private clinics will be closed, while movements in and out of Derik city will be prohibited (excluding emergency cases and food shipments). Humanitarian actors are exempted from these restrictions.

A directive requires the population to wear masks, no enforcement mechanism has been put in place to promote compliance. https://web.archive.org/web/20201124000615/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-response-update-no-12-9-november-2020

The government of Chad first announced that travellers who have been to China, Italy or South Korea will be quarantined for 14 days at a local health facility on 7 March 2020.     The Chad Government issued the first Health Alert on 20 March 2020. Thereafter, On 13 April 2020 the Government finalised the National Contingency Plan for Preparedness and Response to the Epidemic of Coronavirus COVID-19 to prevent the spread of the disease, the Chad Government has taken a series of measures with the major ones focused on: suspension of all international flights, closure of schools, universities, places of worship, and of non-essential businesses, a ban on public transport, closure of the main markets and a curfew in the capital of N’Djamena and 4 provinces of Logone Occidental, Logone Oriental, Mayo-kebbi Ouest and Mayo-kebbi Est.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200501080941/https://reliefweb.int/report/chad/chad-coronavirus-covid-19-situation-report-no-1   https://web.archive.org/web/20200501080113/https://www.cnbcafrica.com/africa-press-office/2020/03/20/health-alert-u-s-embassy-ndjamena-chad/     https://web.archive.org/web/20200501071153/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#C     https://web.archive.org/web/20200501080336/https://www.iata.org/contentassets/b308ae421f9d4f83bec899ea64a04ffc/chad-ncov-measures.pdf

Individuals having traveled to China, South Korea, Iran, Italy, and France will be subject to a coronavirus (COVID-19) test upon arrival on Chadian territory. Depending on the test result, travelers will either be subjected to containment or to a 14-day quarantine period.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200608212225/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/322051/chad-authorities-implement-precautionary-measures-due-to-covid-19-as-of-march-8
Closure of the Cameroonian border with Chad.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200427100127/https://tchadinfos.com/sante/coronavirus-au-tchad-suivez-la-chronologie-des-mesures-prises/
Restriction of gatherings of more than 50 people.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427100127/https://tchadinfos.com/sante/coronavirus-au-tchad-suivez-la-chronologie-des-mesures-prises/

Chad recorded it's first case on March 19 (https://web.archive.org/web/20200525092808/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-chad/chad-confirms-first-case-of-coronavirus-government-statement-idUSKBN2162LO)   "A lack of coronavirus testing (...) explains the country’s high mortality rate"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200511210948/http://www.rfi.fr/en/africa/20200508-chad-begins-coronavirus-lockdown-amid-lack-of-covid-19-testing  Ministry of Health is conducting some tests, but in a restrictive way https://web.archive.org/web/20200511211603/https://sante-tchad.org/covid-19-communique-n-21-du-ministere-de-la-sante-publique/

There is evidence that contact tracing has been in place in Chad, albeit in a limited fashion. The first situation report from UNICEF, covering a period from April 1 - April 15th, notes "As of 13 April 2020, a total of 339 out of 339 (100%) of contacts have been traced and are followed up" However, the same report also notes the challenges of contact tracing, particularly in smaller communities. Source (not archivable): https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Chad%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20No.%201%20-%20for%201-15%20April%202020.pdf

On March 27, 2020, BEAC announced a set of monetary easing measures including a decrease of the policy rate by 25 bps to 3.25 percent, a decrease of the Marginal Lending Facility rate by 100 bps to 5 percent, a suspension of absorption operations, an increase of liquidity provision from FCFA 240 to 500 billion, and a widening of the range of private instruments accepted as collateral in monetary operations. The MPC also supported BEAC’s management’s intent to propose to reduce haircuts applicable to private instruments accepted as collateral for refinancing operations, and to postpone by one-year principal repayment of consolidated central bank’s credits to member states, but these possible additional measures are not effective yet. On March 25, 2020, the COBAC informed banks that they can use their capital conservation buffers of 2.5 percent to absorb pandemic-related losses but requested banks to adopt a restrictive policy with regard to dividend distribution.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200501114637/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The Government of Chad announced a mandatory curfew in several provinces bordering Cameroon between 7pm and 6am starting April 2 for at least two weeks. The curfew applies to N’Djamena and the regions of Logone Occidental, Logone Oriental, Mayo Kebbi Ouest and Mayo Kebbi Est. "La prise de la Pierre Sacrée, édition 2020 annulée  Publié le mercredi, 09 septembre 2020 11:55     (Togo Officiel) - Initialement prévue pour ce jeudi 10 septembre, « la cérémonie de la 357ème édition de la prise de la Pierre Sacrée de cette année 2020 n’aura pas lieu ». C’est ce qu’a annoncé le Trône royal de Glidji (préfecture des Lacs), autorité organisatrice de l’évènement.    La décision est prise en respect aux directives gouvernementales concernant les fêtes traditionnelles, et afin d’éviter la contamination à grande échelle de la population dans l’espace Guin, comme cela a pu être observé dans d’autres localités où se sont déroulées des festivités traditionnelles et culturelles.    Un bouclage préventif de la préfecture avait été également annoncé, toujours afin de limiter au mieux la propagation.    Lire aussi  "  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200913233222/https://www.republiquetogolaise.com/culture/0909-4619-la-prise-de-la-pierre-sacree-edition-2020-annulee

"Last Updated: 09/04/2020  While numbers of COVID-19 cases remain relatively low in Togo, the country extended its state of emergency for the second time, until Sept. 15. Borders are closed, public meetings of more than 15 people are banned, and schools are closed except for certain grades in which exams are mandatory. Masks are required in public. Churches are partially opened."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200913233915/https://www.compassion.com/crisis/covid-19/togo-covid19.htm

Is a curfew in place? [Yes]    On July 9, the Government lifted the curfew that was put in place on April 1.    Source: Covid-19.gouv  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? [Yes]    On August 24, the Government of Togo imposed a curfew in Sokodé (211 miles north of Lomé) and in the neighboring cities of Tchamba (19 miles east of Sokodé) and Adjengré (27 miles south). These measures are intended to limit a possible spread of COVID-19 cases in those locations following an increase in cases there. All land border crossings with Ghana, Burkina Faso and Benin remain closed. If you reside outside of Togo in West Africa,  please contact the U.S. Embassy in your country for assistance. For a detailed list of the flights available in country, visit our COVID-19 page.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200913222242/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/

"Are commercial flights operating? [Yes]"    "Are U.S. citizens required to quarantine? [Yes]    You should expect to spend one to two days under personal quarantine at a hotel or private residence in Lomé. You should limit your contact with anyone during this time. After this period, if it is determined by the Togo Ministry of Health from your nasal swab that you may have COVID-19, you will be required to quarantine for 14 to 21 days at the Eda-Oba Hotel in Lomé at your own expense until being cleared by the Ministry of Health to resume your activities in Togo.    The U.S. Embassy in Lomé will not intervene in a Togo required quarantine unless the quarantine exceeds 21 days and you have submitted to at least three nasal swab tests during quarantine."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200913222242/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/

While there are no discernible policies, the Ministry of Health's posturing appears to indicate a general availability depending on geographical location, yet doesn't indicate individual requirements from the patients' angle.    "Si pour l'heure, la date de la réouverture des frontières togolaises n'a pas encore été officialisée, le gouvernement a en revanche décidé de rendre le test de dépistage du coronavirus payant. "Tout est gratuit jusqu’à maintenant pour identifier le maximum de cas, les confiner et les traiter. Avec l’ouverture prochaine des frontières, il y aura beaucoup de demandes. Les tests devront être facturés", précise Wembo Halatoko, la directrice générale de l’Institut national d’hygiène (INH) à nos confrères de Republicoftogo. Selon les principaux bruits de couloir, le test virologique par PCR (dans le nez) de la Covid-19 sera facturée aux alentours de 65.000 FCFA, soit l'équivalent de 100 euros. "    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200914142040/https://allodocteurs.africa/actualites/epidemie/covid-19/coronavirus-au-togo-un-test-de-depistage-payant-des-la-reouverture-des-frontieres    "Another policy announced by Lomé is to systematically test chief districts that have passed the threshold of 10 cases set by the coordinating team. This, according to the head of the team, Col. Djibril Mohaman, has already been done in Kouvon, a village located in the Tchaoudjo prefecture. As a result, no new case has been recorded there since then. "    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200914142720/https://www.togofirst.com/en/health/2605-5593-test-treat-track-togo-s-strategy-to-contain-the-covid-19-pandemic

Is a curfew in place? [Yes]  Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? [Yes]  As part of the monitoring of the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic, in response to the Coronavirus, the Government of Togo has been observing a worrying increase in new cases of coronavirus infection throughout the country for several weeks, particularly in the following towns: Sokodé, Tchamba and Adjengré.  Having noted that the infected persons have had many contacts, and in order to prevent this spread from increasing further in the populations of these localities and throughout the country, the government has decided the following as of August 25, 2020:  1- The closure of the cities of: Sokodé, Tchamba and Adjengre.  2- The establishment of a curfew from 21.00 to 5.00 in the prefectures of Tchaoudjo, Tchamba and Sotouboua.  All land border crossings with Ghana, Burkina Faso and Benin remain closed. If you reside outside of Togo in West Africa,  please contact the U.S. Embassy in your country for assistance. For a detailed list of the flights available in country, visit our COVID-19 page.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201015075535/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/

The U.S. Embassy in Lomé will not intervene in a Togo required quarantine unless the quarantine exceeds 21 days and you have submitted to at least three nasal swab tests during quarantine    https://web.archive.org/web/20201015075535/https://tg.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/security-and-travel-information/covid-19/

July 1  Reuters- Thai schools reopened on Wednesday for the first time since mid-March, with precautions in place to guard against the coronavirus, ranging from temperature checks to installing makeshift cubicles for social distancing in classrooms.    Chulalongkorn University reopening :As of July 1, 2020, its workplaces within and outside the Bangkok Metropolis be opened and operated as normal’. Coded as a 1 as this indicates universities are able to reopen, therefore, all levels of schooling and university able to open as of July 1.      Reuters Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200705020142/https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-thailand-school/schools-reopen-across-thailand-with-temperature-checks-masks-idUKKBN24253A    University Source: http://archive.vn/WE9u4

July 1  Thailand will allow international flights starting from July 1 for people meeting certain criteria (such as those in need of medical treatment, students, and those with resident permits). It issues an International Permit Flight effective from July 1 to give this access. Travellers will still be subject to mandatory mask wearing on flights, thermal scans and temperature checks on arrival. Six of Thailand's international airports are also reopening on July 1st, handling both domestic and international arrivals. (Don Mueang, Phuket, Chiang Mai, Hat Yai, Chiang Rai, and Suvarnabhumi).    Coded as a 3 as this still does not permit everyone who may wish to, to enter.    Media source: http://archive.vn/5V2IV    Government Public Relations Department Source: http://archive.vn/r8E1Q

Most measures expire in June. Unable to find evidence of their renewal besides this:  “In addition to the refund, the MWA announced it would reduce water bills by 3% for users in Bangkok, Nonthaburi and Samut Prakan for three months, from May to July 2020”.  Source: http://archive.vn/91omp    This source mentions “An earlier subsidy, which lowered monthly power bills from March to May, had helped those struggling with increased living costs during the lockdown and work-from-home period”, but does not suggest this was extended into July.  http://archive.vn/IgYsz      Coded as a 1 from July as can only find evidence of narrow relief from July.

For the Jenny (the singer) concert in the Cha-Uat sub-district administrative office in  Nakhon Sri Thammarat on 25 July 2020, it was found that the COVID-19 prevention  measures are below the government standards and there was a high chance of COVID-19  transmission. The government asked the people who attended that concert to get a free  COVID-19 test at the Cha-Uat district office, Nakhon Sri Thammarat during 4-5 August 2020,  from 9.00-15.00. The Ministry of Public Health is collaborating with local government  agencies to provide the testing service to the people by using the five medical mobile vans  provided by the King.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200814001918/https://ddc.moph.go.th/viralpneumonia/eng/file/news/news_no190_040863.pdf

The domestic flights have reassumed with safety measures including requiring passengers and staff to wear face masks, gloves, keep social distancing and avoid serving food on the plane.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200827150839/https://th.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

If the Thai health authorities notice peple with fever and flu-like symptoms, and have traveled internationally or had close contact with a known COVID-19 case within the past 14 days, they will be placed in isolation and required to undergo testing which can take up to 48 hours. If positive, they will be hospitalized until symptoms resolve and they have two negative tests separated by 24 hours.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200827150839/https://th.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

"Domestic Flights to Resume Under Strict Guidelines: The CAAT has announced new guidelines for the operation of domestic flights within Thailand.  The key measures include: 1) passengers must wear face masks and gloves at all times; 2) passengers must adhere to airlines’ social distancing requirements from check-in and boarding through landing and there must be empty seats between passengers; 3) flight crews will wear masks and gloves at all times; and 4) flight crews will not serve food or beverages on the plane and passengers are prohibited from bringing outside food on the plane."  https://th.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

There is no curfew in place or restrictions on intercity or interstate travel. See: https://th.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ [accessed 5 October 2020, webpage last updated on 1 October 2020, web archive unavailable]

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs has reassured the public that it will continue to assist Thai citizens who wish to travel back to Thailand during the COVID-19 pandemic. It has also relaxed measures for foreign nationals traveling to Thailand, which will stimulate the economy. So far, they have already issued 40,401 certificates of entry (COE) for foreign nationals entering Thailand. The groups of foreign nationals who have traveled to Thailand the most are (1) foreign nationals who hold a valid work permit, (2) foreign nationals who are the spouse, parent, or child of a Thai national, and (3) students in educational institutions. All of them have been in quarantine in accordance with the Government's measures. (28/11/2020)  https://web.archive.org/web/20201129200850/https://thailand.prd.go.th/more_news.php?cid=2&filename=index
no changes noted - https://web.archive.org/web/20201129200850/https://thailand.prd.go.th/more_news.php?cid=2&filename=index

The Tajik Ministry of Health sent a letter to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the country's tourism development committee, in which it asked departments to restrict both business and leisure trips of Tajik citizens to China.    The Deputy Minister of Health of Tajikistan noted that preventive work is being carried out in all regions of the country, laboratories are prepared for the on-line examination of citizens who arrived from China.    The deputy minister also added that the situation in Tajikistan remains stable so far, there have not been any cases of coronavirus among Tajik citizens, and all visitors from China are screened to identify signs of a dangerous disease. All airports are equipped with quarantine points.      Kamolzoda asked the Tajiks to refrain from flying to China for a while. According to him, "it is impossible to restrict the entry of citizens of other countries into our country," but, for security reasons, we will check all citizens coming from China, including Tajiks. "    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200529133937/https://regnum.ru/news/polit/2835826.html

The Khovar state news agency has reported that between February 1 and April 30, nearly 11,000 people have been placed in preventative quarantine. Of that total, 8,438 were discharged without showing signs of ill-health. More than 2,000 are still under observation.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200528225850/https://eurasianet.org/tajikistan-finally-confirms-its-first-15-coronavirus-cases

Students, businessmen, Chinese citizens working in Tajikistan, who arrived from China, total 300 people, were quarantined for 14 days. However, they did not show signs of coronavirus. This was reported by the Ministry of Health and Social Protection of the Population of Tajikistan.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200529133052/https://regnum.ru/news/society/2847860.html

According to Tajik Deputy Minister of Health Mirhamuddin Kamolzoda, only patients with signs of the virus will be tested. To date, none have been identified in the country.    Tajikistan received a large batch of Russian diagnostic tools, but the Ministry of Health plans to use them only in case of the appearance of primary signs of coronavirus.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200529131935/https://regnum.ru/news/society/2849024.html

Tajikistan notified local and foreign airlines that it would block the entry of citizens from a list of 35 countries which have had confirmed cases of the coronavirus. The countries include (with their number of confirmed cases as of March 3 in parentheses: China (80,151), South Korea (5,186), Italy (2,036), Iran (1,501), Japan (274), Spain (120), Singapore (108), United States (105), Kuwait (56), Bahrain (49), Thailand (43), Switzerland (42), the United Kingdom (40), Malaysia (36), Australia (31), Canada (27), Iraq (26), United Arab Emirates (21), Austria (18), Vietnam (16), Sweden (15), Lebanon (13), Israel (12), Croatia (9), Belgium (8), Finland (6),  Oman (6), Algeria (5), India (5), the Philippines (3), Egypt (2), Afghanistan (1), Cambodia (1), Nepal (1) and Sri Lanka (1).     Missing from the list, but with more than 100 cases, are France (191) and Germany (165). In addition, states in neighboring regions with recent cases like Georgia (3), Azerbaijan (3) and Armenia (1) are also not on the ban list, yet.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200528130301/https://www.interfax.ru/world/697502

Wearing masks is mandatory in public transports and public spaces only.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200907105336/https://tj.sputniknews.ru/health/20200316/1030886645/tajikistan-koronavirus-maski-zashchita-proizvodstvo.html

Tajikistan strengthens anti-epidemic measures.      In accordance with the order of the President of Tajikistan dated March 18, 2020, in order to implement measures to prevent the spread of new coronavirus infection (COVID - 19), the Republican headquarters was established to strengthen anti-epidemic measures.    The management of the headquarters is entrusted to the Prime Minister of the Republic of Tajikistan Kohir Rasulzoda.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200529124529/https://asiaplustj.info/ru/news/tajikistan/power/20200320/kohir-rasulzoda-vozglavil-novii-shtab-po-usileniyu-protivoepidemicheskih-meropriyatii

The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of Tajikistan reports that temporary restrictions have been introduced on the entry and exit of all citizens of foreign countries and stateless persons through all checkpoints on the state borders of the Republic of Tajikistan.    These restrictions do not apply to diplomats of foreign states and representatives of international organizations and financial institutions, as well as members of their families accredited in the Republic of Tajikistan. In case of entry of the specified category of persons into the territory of the republic, the procedure of compulsory 14-day self-isolation in the places of their permanent residence under the supervision of employees of the Ministry of Health and Social Welfare of the Republic of Tajikistan is provided.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200528130447/https://www.mfa.tj/ru/main/view/5919/vremennye-ogranicheniya-na-vezd-i-vyezd-inostrannykh-grazhdan-i-lits-bez-grazhdanstva-cherez-punkty-propuska-na-gosudarstvennoi-granitse-tadzhikistana

15 June  OCHA Relief Web Tajikistan Situation report 11. As of 15 June 2020, all the public facilities, clothing markets, shopping malls, beauty salons, sanatoriums, restaurants and others, which have been temporary closed due to COVID-19 related epidemiological situation have re-opened. However, limitations of mass gatherings are still valid, prohibiting mass prayers in mosques and mass gatherings at different traditional ceremonies (weddings, funerals, etc). June 19  Up to 50,000 low-income families with young children in Tajikistan will receive a one-time payment of 500 Tajik somoni as emergency social assistance. These payments are provided as part of the World Bank-financed Tajikistan Emergency COVID-19 Project (TEC-19), which is supporting Tajikistan’s efforts in responding to the health and social risks associated with the global COVID-19 pandemic.  NOTE: this funding has been given to the government from external sources such as the World Bank.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200628120135/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2020/06/19/world-bank-supported-project-finances-cash-transfers-to-protect-vulnerable-children-in-tajikistan  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200618201302/https://reliefweb.int/report/uzbekistan/world-bank-s-covid-19-response-europe-and-central-asia-glance-enru

According to state media and a press release from the ministry of foreign affairs, an order from January 8th introduced "enhanced security and control measures in border areas that will be applied for citizens leaving and arriving in Turkmenistan. https://web.archive.org/web/20200531234215/https://arzuw.news/vvodjatsja-povyshennye-mery-protiv-infekcionnyh-zabolevanij; https://web.archive.org/web/20200531235438/https://www.mfa.gov.tm/ru/news/1848

According to the Turkmeni Ministry of Foreign Affairs, an order from the Ministry of Health from January 8 provided a case definition for coronavirus. Those  arriving individuals are also subject to quarantine measures."   https://web.archive.org/web/20200601001001/https://www.mfa.gov.tm/en/news/1848; https://web.archive.org/web/20200601001204/https://www.undocs.org/en/A/74/848

On January 20, a meeting of the Extraordinary Commission on combatting the spread of diseases was held. "ASHGABAT, Feb 1 (Reuters) - Turkmenistan Airlines, the Central Asian nation’s state carrier, has suspended flights to and from Beijing, the company said on Saturday.    The move was aimed at preventing the spread of the 2019-nCoV virus which has prompted many other nations to suspend travel links with China, the company said in a statement."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200508194247/https://www.reuters.com/article/china-health-turkmenistan-flights/turkmenistan-airlines-suspends-air-link-with-beijing-over-virus-outbreak-idUSR4N29W02C

Turkmenistan distributes booklets informing about the dangers of coronavirus, allows school children to wear face masks and starts campaign in schools and local institutions; https://web.archive.org/web/20200531235001/https://rus.azathabar.com/a/30426223.html; https://web.archive.org/web/20200531235006/https://www.hronikatm.com/2020/02/virus-2/

The government of Turkmenistan introduced a blockade regime in Ashgabat and limited the movement of citizens between the regions of the country.   Citizens are not allowed to leave their areas of residence.   You can only leave in exceptional cases, and before that you need to get special permission from local administrations.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200518235414/https://ru.krymr.com/a/news-koronavirus-ashhabsd-zakryli/30499268.html

"ALMATY (Reuters) - Authorities in Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan and Turkmenistan have announced fresh restrictions aimed at preventing the spread of coronavirus as the number of cases in Central Asia rose.     In Turkmenistan, which has so far reported no coronavirus cases, locals traveling to and from the capital, Ashgabat, said that officials at checkpoints set up around the city informed them that non-essential travel was banned.    The Turkmen government, which earlier suspended all international flights, has made no official announcements on the scope and duration of the new restrictions."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200508195314/https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-centralasia/central-asia-tightens-restrictions-as-coronavirus-spreads-idUSKBN218090

Correspondents report the closure of sports halls and fitness studios in Ashgabat. Measures have been taken as prevention of the spread of coronavirus.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200519000802/https://www.hronikatm.com/2020/03/sporting-events-postponed/

Correspondents report the cancellation of all sporting events and training of athletes in Turkmenistan. Measures have been taken as prevention of the spread of coronavirus.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200519000802/https://www.hronikatm.com/2020/03/sporting-events-postponed/

Schools are open. However, the government is leading an information campaign on sanitary measures due to COVID-19 among school learners. Consequently, school operations result in significant differences as compared to usual, non-Covid-19 operations.    Link: https://archive.vn/bdh45

Gyms and sports clubs reopen in Ashgabat on April 1. Further article from April 7 suggest that cafes and restaurants are open again as well; https://web.archive.org/web/20200531230807/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19 (gyms and sports clubs); https://web.archive.org/web/20200531230950/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-52186521 (cafes and restaurants)

Turkmenistan resumed football season despite coronavirus pandemic. The Ministry of Sports said the decision to resume the football season “pleased the army of fans” and was supported by the players.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200519012131/https://rus.azathabar.com/a/30565770.html

Turkmenistan has reopened most of its border crossing points and is preparing to open the rest on the border with Iran: https://web.archive.org/web/20200519011327/https://rus.azathabar.com/a/30571830.html

"All commercial passenger flights in and out of Turkmenistan are suspended. See Return to the UK. Mandatory quarantine is in place for all arrivals from abroad for up to 14 days. See Entry requirements."  web.archive.org/web/20200706225920/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/staying-during-coronavirus    All international commercial flights to and from Turkmenistan have been cancelled and?land borders?are?closed?to passenger traffic. International?flight restrictions are expected to continue at least through?October 1, 2020.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200909112702/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    At present, entry to Turkmenistan is prohibited except for Turkmen nationals and accredited diplomats, permanently registered foreigners and some employees of international companies and organizations  https://web.archive.org/web/20200816123428/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan

No officially reported cases currently. Concerns raised by HRW of lack of transparency + lack of encouragement for social distancing and other public health measures. Since initial info booklets in Feb, unable to find official coordinated public information. The country has been involved in an international briefings and does encourage citizens to maintain hygiene and general healthy behaviours to protect against disease. https://web.archive.org/web/20200706232115/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/asia-pacific/turkmenistan-hosts-international-briefing-on-covid-19/1834261https://web.archive.org/web/20200706232227/https://www.hrw.org/news/2020/06/27/turkmenistan-denies-apparent-covid-19-outbreak

In a statement published by the state information agency on 13 July 2020, the health ministry "recommended that residents wear masks" because of "high concentrations of dust" in the air.     This announcement was made after a 10-day mission undertaken by a World Health Organization (WHO) delegation to examine the response to the COVID-19 pandemic. This measure was imposed while the government continued to insist Turkmenistan is coronavirus-free.    No original government announcement could be found, but this source has been cited by the Mask4all Dataset and seems reliable.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201022215731/https://www.dailysabah.com/world/asia-pacific/coronavirus-free-turkmenistan-orders-mask-wearing-to-combat-dust
"Newspapers report domestic railway traffic suspensions between July 14-23."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200728065447/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Turkmenistan suspended rail links between provinces this week, closed large shopping venues and banned mass gatherings, but the government did not cite COVID-19 as the reason. It said it was taking precautions against viruses, dust and other harmful substances carried across the region by the wind.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200716014003/https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2020/07/15/world/15reuters-health-coronavirus-turkmenistan.html

Turkmenistan suspended rail links between provinces this week, closed large shopping venues and banned mass gatherings, but the government did not cite COVID-19 as the reason. The Government of Turkmenistan suspended domestic railway traffic between July 14-23.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200728065447/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

There is no confirmation for cancellation of public events.  A public bike ride took place on 3 Jun as part of World Cycling Day per http://web.archive.org/web/20201020204219/https://www.mfa.gov.tm/en/news/2068  and a car rally happened on 19 Oct per  http://web.archive.org/web/20201020204242/https://customs.gov.tm/en/news/1714

Public transport remains severely limited - railways not running and road travel restrictions in place  http://archive.today/2020.10.01-172413/https://rus.azathabar.com/a/30866535.html  http://web.archive.org/web/20201012221726/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

As per below article, there are restrictions on road travel within Turkmenistan. All road borders are closed. Traffic police check points have been established around major population centres, including Ashgabat, and road users may be subject to temperature screening.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201012221726/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

Facemasks are made compulsory from 13 July. Also, parents are being encouraged to educate children about sanitation. Video grab from TV of a campaign : https://t.me/anthabar/604  http://web.archive.org/web/20201012223737/https://en.turkmen.news/news/turkmenistan-makes-face-masks-compulsory-but-remains-silent-on-covid-19/  http://web.archive.org/web/20201012223408/https://en.hronikatm.com/2020/09/schoolchildrens-parents-are-obliged-to-educate-their-children-about-precautionary-measures/

As per this article, there is hardly any testing happening.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201020210458/https://www.hhrjournal.org/2020/10/covid-19-in-turkmenistan-no-data-no-health-rights/  Officially there are no Covid cases in Turkmenistan as per the same source and this one : http://web.archive.org/web/20201020210712/https://wwwnc.cdc.gov/travel/notices/warning/coronavirus-turkmenistan

Not a very authoritative source, but it mentions that from 13 July, face masks are compulsory  http://web.archive.org/web/20201012223737/https://en.turkmen.news/news/turkmenistan-makes-face-masks-compulsory-but-remains-silent-on-covid-19/

According to an update of the US Embassy in Turkmenistan on 8 Sep 2020, it seems the Turkmenistan government has imposed measures to restrict large gatherings. But the cap on the number of people is not clear. According to the archived webpage, such measures were not in place on 13 Aug 2020, and then showed up at latest on 8 Sep 2020. Such measures remain in place.    "Mosques and places of pilgrimage are closed and large gatherings are restricted."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200909112702/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201016191509/https://tm.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

According to an update of the foreign travel advice offered by the UK government on 22 Oct 2020, it seems the Turkmenistan government has recently imposed new measures to cancel public events. According to the archived webpage, such measures were not in place at least on 12 Oct 2020.    "Recreational facilities, non-essential shops, bars and restaurants, entertainment facilities, sports, spa and beauty facilities, and mosques are closed to the public."    This contrasts with an earlier statement on the same website, "no restrictive measures have been put in place by the Turkmen authorities."    Archived webpage before such measures were introduced: https://web.archive.org/web/20201012221726/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus    Archived webpage after such measures were introduced:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022230440/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/turkmenistan/coronavirus

The Ministry of Health began sharing on his Facebook page basic preventive measures against COVID-19, originally posted by WHO.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200528214226/https://www.facebook.com/MinisteriodaSaudeTL?_rdc=1&_rdr=

Screening instituted at entry points — land, air, and sea border controls. This includes  the use of temperature scanning and use of Health Declaration cards at Dili  International Airport. Vigilance and screening has also been introduced at seaports and  land border controls    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200530152808/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/searo/timor-leste/03-02-2020-tls-sitrep-1-ncov-revised.pdf?sfvrsn=cb480d79_2

1) Prohibition of entry into the national territory of foreign citizens who transited in the Hubei Province in the last 4 weeks.  2) Foreigners who have transited in China in the last 4 weeks will have to show a medical certificate.  3) Timorese citizens or foreigners born in Timor-Leste and residing in the country are not forbidden entry  4) Any citizen who comes into the national territory and refuses to go back to their country despite being prohibited must undergo mandatory quarantine.  5) Timorese citizens coming from China should undergo voluntary quarantine of 14 days.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200530145322/http://www.mj.gov.tl/jornal/public/docs/2020/serie_1/SERIE_I_NO_6_A.pdf

Protocols for case detection and contact tracing have been updated based on the new revised  surveillance guidelines. Surveillance teams and rapid responders at national and municipality level have been trained and are on standby to detect and respond to COVID-19 alerts in the country.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200530153458/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/searo/timor-leste/03-03-2020-tls-sitrep-15-ncov-eng.pdf?sfvrsn=e7702ec7_2

There is no official policy document on testing. However, WHO situation reports suggest that tests are underway and that symptomatic patients are being tested: "Currently, there are NO cases of Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID–19). However, the Ministry of Health remains vigilant and ready to respond appropriately as the situation develops. Suspected COVID-19 Case 1 whose test result came as negative from the laboratory in Australia was announced by the Ministry of Health (MoH) in a press conference on Tuesday, 10 March 2020. The person was discharged and poses no threat to public health. Suspected COVID-19 Case 2 test results came as negative. However, since the person still has symptoms, a second swab sample will be collected and sent to Australia for a second test in the next few days. In the meantime, the person is stable and remains in isolation under medical observation. The MoH is monitoring the situation closely with support from WHO and partners. Two more persons – one Timorese and one foreign national were also tested for COVID-19 but the test result from Australia came back as negative. They DO NOT have COVID-19 infection. These did not meet the criteria for the suspected case, but samples were sent by HNGV as a precautionary measure."      Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200604092533/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/searo/timor-leste/11-03-2020-tls-sitrep-17-ncov-eng.pdf?sfvrsn=fb20eee9_2  http://web.archive.org/web/20200604092535/https://www.who.int/docs/default-source/searo/timor-leste/13-03-2020-tls-sitrep-18-ncov-eng.pdf?sfvrsn=9df102cd_2

With government resolution 10/2020, the government prohibits entry to all foreign citizens who come from or have transited in countries affected by Coronavirus in the last 4 weeks, according to WHO regulation. This excludes foreign citizens born in Timor-Leste and that habitually reside here, or that represent legally Timorese minors and foreign minors that reside in Timor-Leste. However they must undergo a period of quarantine of 14 days. The PM can allow exceptions to this rule for national interest or security reasons. All individuals, including Timorese, are forbidden from disembarking cruise ships and enter the national territory.  Business travel of public servants is also prohibited (both direct and indirect state administration offcials). The resolution is effective the day after its publication, hence on March 20.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200523184823/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/JRRes10MedidasExcecionais19Mar2020pt.pdf

On March 22, the Ministry of Education, Youth and Sport announced in a press release that all primary and secondary schools, private and public would close from March 23 to March 28, highlighting that students should stay at home and follow hygiene practices. The Ministry of Higher Education and Culture announced that tertiary education institutions would remain close from March 23 to April 4.     Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200525200928/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/MEJD-21-03-20202en.pdfhttp://web.archive.org/web/20200525200537/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/MEJD-21-03-20202te.pdf    http://web.archive.org/web/20200525200653/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/UnisClose22Mar2020te.pdf

The Ministry of Transport and Communication launched a hotline for citizens to solves doubts and provides assistance on COVID-19-related matters.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200530110247/http://www.tatoli.tl/2020/03/23/governu-kria-lina-telefonika-numeru-119-asesu-informasaun-kona-ba-covid-19/

Government Decree n. 3/2020 of March 28 on the Measures for the Implementation of the Declaration of State of Emergency introduced by Decree of the President of the Republic n.º29/2020, of 27 March, established the following regulation for workplaces:    Public sector: Members of the Government and directors of public legal entities that are part of the indirect administration of the State will identify the human resources strictly necessary to ensure the functioning of their services under the regime of minimum services. Minimum services are those the provision of which provision is essential to ensure the functioning of the Public Administration and the provision, to citizens and companies, of goods and services that are of an urgent nature. Public Administration staff who are exempt from the duty to appear in their workplace must remain reachable by phone and appear whenever summoned by their  hierarchical superior.     Private sector: Commercial and service establishments, markets, and street vendors are allowed. Individuals wishing to access the commercial and services premises are required to use mouth and nose protection mask; clean hands before entering said facilities; respect the distance of at least one meter from other individuals. Those responsible for commercial and services premises have an obligation to make available, at the entrance of their facilities.    These regulations are in place for the entire duration of the State of Emergency, now set to last until April 26, 2020.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200525211506/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/GovDecree3SoEen.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20200525211610/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/F-estado-de-emergencia-iniciativa-privada-2-ENG.pdf

Government Decree 3/2020 ruled that any social, cultural and sporting events that involve the gathering of people is prohibited for the entire state of emergency, lasting from March 28 to April 26.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200523165206/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/02-DL-Medidas-Exec-Dec-Est-Emerg-p-Dec-Pres-Rep-A-01-ENG_FULL-DOC_MC_REV_final-version-B-02-VLL-final.pdf

In decree n.º 3/2020 of March 28th, the government ruled for the prohibition of the gathering of more than 5 people. The prohibition holds for the entire period of declared State of Emergency, not set to end on April 26, 2020.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200525205218/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/GovDecree3SoEen.pdf

Law decree 3/2020 rules that collective passenger transport activities are suspended for the entire period of state of emergency. The state of emergency is in force between 00:00 hours on March 28, 2020 and 23:59 hours on April 26, 2020 and applies to the entire national territory.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200523165206/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/02-DL-Medidas-Exec-Dec-Est-Emerg-p-Dec-Pres-Rep-A-01-ENG_FULL-DOC_MC_REV_final-version-B-02-VLL-final.pdf

Government decree 3/2020 established the following:   (1) Individuals who are not subject to mandatory isolation and who do not carry out any  professional activity or can work from home have to remain inside their homes and limit their movement outside to the minimum necessary, including to go to the doctor, to go grocery shopping, or for important matters.  (2) Compulsory isolation in a health facility or their homes applies to all those infected with Coronavirus until they are discharged.  (3) Compulsory isolation for all individuals who enter the national territory for at  14 days  Link: http://timor-leste.gov.tl/wp-content/uploads/2020/03/02-DL-Medidas-Exec-Dec-Est-Emerg-p-Dec-Pres-Rep-A-01-ENG_FULL-DOC_MC_REV_final-version-B-02-VLL-final.pdf

The Ministry of Public Works established a 15$ subsidy for electricity fees.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200604085819/https://www.facebook.com/antsampaio/posts/10158067670813399  http://web.archive.org/web/20200604085853/http://www.tatoli.tl/2020/03/30/mop-deside-fo-subsidiu-pre-pagu-eletrisidade-15-ba-kliente-hamutuk-170-555/

The government amended decree 3/2020 and ruled for closing borders to all individuals, foreigners and Timorese from April 13 until further notice.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200528211251/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/MFA8Apr2020en.png

The government approved additional financial support:   1. Subsidy internet access to students   2. Maintained subsidy for electricity fees of $15 per month  3. Suspension of payments for water fees  4. Suspension of social security payments and payment of rent on government property    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200606082004/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/?p=24159&n=1&lang=pt  http://web.archive.org/web/20200604084550/http://www.tatoli.tl/2020/04/22/governu-hakarak-oferese-tan-subsidiu-pre-pagu-eletrisidade-ba-fulan-tolu/  http://web.archive.org/web/20200606082147/http://www.tatoli.tl/2020/04/29/governu-aprova-millaun-2-hodi-fo-subsidiu-ba-estudante/

Everyone must wash or sanitize their hands before entering commercial establishments or service providing facilities, wear a mask that protects their mouth and nose, and maintain a distance of one meter (three feet) from others.  This applies to stores, markets, and other venues.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201012153140/https://tl.usembassy.gov/health-alert-u-s-embassy-dili-timor-leste-april-21-2020/

In Government Decree no. 8/2020 of April 30 on the Measures for the Implementation of the Declaration of State of Emergency introduced by Decree of the President of the Republic no. 32/2020, of 27 April, the Government ruled that public transport is permitted, under the public p provided that (1) vehicles are cleaned daily before starting each journey, (2) drivers, crews and passengers wear protective masks, (3) individuals are refused entry if they do not comply, (4) Social distancing is adopted among passengers.    This regulation holds for the entire State of Emergency, now set to end on May 27, 2020.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200525203857/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/D8-2020MedidasEE30Apr2020en.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20200525203950/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/?p=24225&lang=en

The government approved a monthly payment of US $100 per household as a short-term intervention to address a specific threat to livelihoods, the economy, and society as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. It applies to all households with monthly incomes of up to US $500 that are registered in the national "Register of Uma Kain" (neighborhood-level registry). Given that average income is $40 for rural households and $206 for urban households, according to the 2011 Household Income and Expenditure Survey 2011, this transfer exceeds 50% of lost income. Payments will be financed by the COVID-19 Fund.    Additionally, in a separate diploma, the government established support measures for the private sector, comprising employers and employees, provided that persons are registered in the social security contribution scheme. In particular, it grants:  a) a subsidy of up to 60% of the wage cost and b) exemption from the duty to pay social security contributions, for formal sector workers who have to be quarantined or stay at home during the pandemic. The support is financed by the COVID-19 Fund.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200602212101/http://www.statistics.gov.tl/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/HIES2011_Report_20-_20Final.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20200602212115/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/DL15HouseholdSupport30Apr2020en.pdf   http://web.archive.org/web/20200602213733/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/DL16SubsEmprego30Apr2020en.pdf

27 May    The government approved an extension on the state of emergency, whose restrictions now only regard to the sanitary control at the entrance and exit points of the national territory, circulation in national territory and establishment of residence are maintained. The execution measures relating to school closure are clarified in a decree approved on April 29, stating the following:    Pre-school, primary education, secondary education, higher education, and vocational or technical-vocational training establishments may carry out school activities on a face-to-face basis. The performance of school activities in person will depend on compliance with the technical standards that are approved for this purpose by the Minister of Health in coordination with the relevant government.The ministry of education receives approval by the ministry of health on the procedures and standards implemented for the reopening of schools. Teaching will officially restart once the ministry of education has verified that all schools in the territory are following the required standards.    Link: http://web.archive.org/web/20200614075106/http://www.tatoli.tl/2020/06/05/ms-aprova-pedidu-mejd-re-ativa-ensinu-aprendijazen/    Link:   http://web.archive.org/web/20200606073432/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/JRPresDec35Lei4-27Maiu2020pt.pdf  http://web.archive.org/web/20200606071429/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/?p=24530&lang=en  http://web.archive.org/web/20200606073342/http://www.laohamutuk.org/Justice/2020/GovDec9-29May2020en.pdf

The government approved an extension on the state of emergency, whose restrictions now only regard to the sanitary control at the entrance and exit points of the national territory, circulation in national territory and establishment of residence are maintained. The execution measures relating to workplace closure are clarified in a decree approved on April 29 stating the following:    As in the previous regulation, private businesses are allowed to operate provided that they implement social distancing and sanitary measures.     Now the public sector is also allowed to operate at full capacity. They must ensure social distance and that implement sanitary measures. "Timorese citizens and foreign nationals can obtain COVID-19 testing at the National Hospital, free of charge. Those seeking to test should call the COVID-19 hotline at +670-7556-0000 via WhatsApp first to receive further guidance on scheduling testing. Fees for testing may be imposed and those seeking testing should confirm the cost when scheduling an appointment."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200831010604/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

On September 23, the government decided to distribute cash transfers for basic staple foods to eligible households, worth US$25 per month per household, lasting for 2 months (November and December) to provide short-term economic stimulus and encourage production and trade, as part of the Economic Recovery Plan.     The beneficiaries of the basic food basket are those who are members of households registered in the “Uma-Kain Register Book” and who are on national territory when the basic food basket is distributed, as well as Timorese citizens who currently attend social, educational, religious, health or prison institutions on a boarding or imprisonment  basis, and for this purpose, they will be treated separately from the respective households listed in the “Uma-Kain Register Book”.    The food basket may be replaced by a shopping voucher for the corresponding goods, in the same amount.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200930222657/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/?p=25696&lang=en  https://web.archive.org/web/20200930223925/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

During the state of emergency, all individuals, should wear a face mask covering the nose and mouth when they have to remain in closed public spaces and frequently sanitizing their hands, namely at the entrance of business premises and public administration service buildings.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201014013705/http://timor-leste.gov.tl/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/EN-CdI_RCM_2020-10-03.pdf

No policy change  Schools reopened since June 2020 however Health Minister Odete Maria Freitas Belo said they must abide by Covid-19 health protocols. “The safety, security and happiness of children must be the top priority. Students have to wear a mask. Each school has to prepare hand-washing facilities and ensure physical distancing,”     https://web.archive.org/web/20201116110950/https://www.ucanews.com/news/schools-in-timor-leste-set-to-reopen/88312

State of emergency extended till December 3rd.  (Refer to the below link)  http://web.archive.org/web/20201130092546/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    In the state of emergency: "You are required to wear a protective mask covering your mouth and nose and a safe distance of at least 1.5 meters must be observed. Anyone who displays a body temperature of higher than 37.5°C, or has a sore throat, or a cold, or respiratory distress including shortness of breath is forbidden to board buses, ships or aircrafts (the only exception is in the case of medical evacuation). Grocery shops, fuel stations, pharmacies, clinics, banking facilities and building material stores remain open but enforce a 1 metre minimum distance between each person."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201130094305/https://travelbans.org/asia/east-timor/

All persons entering the country are required to be quarantined for 14 days in facilities established by the government, or in their respective residences subject to the pre-approval of the Ministry of Health.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130094305/https://travelbans.org/asia/east-timor/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201116113227/https://tl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

"On January 30, 2020 the Cabinet took the decision to impose travel restrictions on anyone who had been in China for a 14 days period prior to their arrival in Trinidad and Tobago. We imposed the restriction that any non-national who had been in China for a period of 14 days prior to their arrival in Trinidad and Tobago would not be permitted entry and any national or resident who fell into this category would be quarantined until it was clear that they were not affected by COVID 19."    (https://web.archive.org/web/20200413110343/https://www.opm.gov.tt/prime-minister-dr-the-hon-keith-rowleys-parliament-statement-on-covid-19/)

First announcement on Government website with advice to the public regarding coronavirus.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200430110210/http://www.news.gov.tt/content/no-confirmed-or-suspected-cases-novel-coronavirus-date-all-screening-protocols-place

Since March 19: the Trinidad and Tobago Electricity Commission “will immediately stop disconnections as a result of non-payment.  This will directly impact 87% of residential customers, who are most likely experiencing financial vulnerability at this time.”  http://web.archive.org/web/20200504191719/http://www.news.gov.tt/content/implementation-social-support-measures-covid-19  March: “over 3,800 VAT refund payments in cash were made to businesses with outstanding arrears of $250,000 per VAT period or less, at a cost of $260 million (...) as for Income Tax, to date, $116 million in income tax refunds of $20,000 or less has been paid to 17,195 individuals with $124 million approved for payment to another 7,900 individuals within the next two weeks, clearing off all outstanding individual income tax refunds, at a cost of $240 million”.  “The period covered by the VAT Return is referred to as the tax period. The standard tax period is two (2) months (...) Each return is due on or before the 25th day of the month following the end of the tax period. ”  More information about the measures could be found in the following links:   http://web.archive.org/web/20200504184415/https://www.looptt.com/content/imbert-budget-pegged-us25-oil-price-deficit-revised-155b  http://web.archive.org/web/20200504223438/http://www.ird.gov.tt/submission-of-the-vat-return    See later update.

Public gatherings limited to 10 people. "On March 21, the GOTT announced restrictions on gatherings at public places." (https://web.archive.org/web/20200413124105/https://tt.usembassy.gov/information-on-government-of-trinidad-and-tobago-stay-at-home-order-public-health-ordinance/)

From 6 April, the Ministry of Health *advised* the general population to use face masks or coverings in public to reduce the spread of the pandemic.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200901015609/https://www.facebook.com/MinistryofHealthTT/posts/3254145621281890

“Income Support Grants of up to $1,500 per month per household, for persons who are outside of the NIS and BIR systems who have lost their jobs or incomes as a result of COVID-19.” The first payment “was wired to the bank accounts of recipients on Tuesday evening [April 28]”. The assistance represents more than 50% of the minimum wage in Trinidad and Tobago, that is of $15 TT per hour or, approximately, $2,250 TT per month. Here’s the links that explain the extraordinary measures during COVID:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200504184415/https://www.looptt.com/content/imbert-budget-pegged-us25-oil-price-deficit-revised-155b  http://web.archive.org/web/20200504201630/https://www.looptt.com/content/first-set-salary-relief-grants-wired-bank-accounts-recipients    Since May 1, the government also launched a “new emergency food support to new beneficiaries in which 30,000 food baskets would be delivered to citizens over four months. Included in the basket would be a $250 supermarket voucher, two chickens, and locally grown fruits and vegetables sourced by Namdevco.” The voucher represents 11% of the minimum wage.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200504201709/https://newsday.co.tt/2020/05/03/fraudsters-tap-into-covid19-grants/  The government has also developed a Rental Assistance program, that “will be paid directly to the landlords and not tenants.” Specific amounts of the assistance were not found.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200504184322/https://www.looptt.com/content/over-85-million-spent-covid-19-relief-date-minister-reveals  The executed payments in each program are available here:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200504184149/http://news.gov.tt/content/here-are-some-quick-facts-about-social-support-grants-covid-19-and-how-apply-them

According to question and answers section on Ministry of Health of TTO visited 10th May mentions "This will be determined by the public health officials depending on the evolving situation. These are in accordance with the guidance provided by the World Health Organization. Not everyone with flu-like symptoms needs to be tested. At this time, if you do not fit the criteria, testing will not be performed. Factors such as clinical history, travel history and/or contact with a COVID-19 positive patient are considered.https://web.archive.org/web/20200509200836/http://www.health.gov.tt/sitepages/default.aspx?id=305

In line with phased reopening announced by government, Phase II began on May 21 and allowed additional industries beyond essential businesses to open.    Government graphic explaining closure stages  https://web.archive.org/web/20200528205540/https:/twitter.com/newsgovtt/status/1263153842201509891/photo/1    Story about manufacturing opening:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200528210025/http://www.guardian.co.tt/news/slow-phase-2-reopening-for-some-businesses-6.2.1121329.a259194645
